title: Data Use Club seminar: Biosecurity alerts
description: During the next Data Use Club <> webinar, three speakers from the Science and Decision Support Team at theAtlas of Living Australia <https://www.ala.org.au/> (ALA) will share their insights on how early surveillance and incursion detection of invasive species is a crucial component of an effective biosecurity system. Australia is a global leader in biosecurity, as is reflected in its biosecurity measures being among the most stringent and recognizable in the world.<br class="mb-4">Australia's native flora, fauna and environment have experienced some of greatest impacts from invasive species as a result of its history of accidental and deliberate introductions.Callum Waite, Erin Roger and Shandiya Balasubramaniam will describe their work in developing a biosecurity alert system prototype that relies on the experimentalR package koel <https://github.com/AtlasOfLivingAustralia/koel>, which ingests species lists, applies spatial, temporal, and taxonomic filters to occurrence records from the ALA, and emails users updates on species of concern.<br class="mb-4">NOTE: This session will start at 9:00 CET to better accommodate our Australia-based speakers<br class="mb-4">Speakers<br class="mb-4"> * Callum Waite <https://orcid.org/0009-0009-0474-0122>  * Erin Roger <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9671-132X>, Sector Lead  * Shandiya Balasubramaniam <https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9928-9964>, Decision Support Program Lead  Register <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZMscO-hrT0tHtGhKnsJQoJk6hdoixwByJsE> <br class="mb-4">Email questions, comments or feedback to datause@gbif.org <mailto:datause@gbif.org>

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: March 2024
description: The theme for the March 2024 session of the Technical Support Hour for Node is GBIF’s data quality workflow. We will go through how published data is processed regarding quality checks, show how you can get an overview of the flags and issues of datasets, how users provide publicly accessible feedback and how you can navigate the feedback yourself.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZUkfuCupj8iH92pS7BE9VbYfkSL-Q7j9IyC> <br class="mb-4">If nodes and node staff have ideas for topics, or questions please post them in the community forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/gbifs-data-quality-workflow-gbif-technical-support-hour-for-nodes/4286> or email them tohelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>

title: Webinar: Data4Nature: An Introduction to GBIF Data Publishing
description: <br class="mb-4">The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development <https://www.ebrd.com> (EBRD) is seeking to improve its biodiversity data disclosure practices by sharing biodiversity data generated through EBRD-financed projects with GBIF, the world’s largest open source repository of biodiversity data. Data sharing with GBIF has potential to make a substantial contribution to global science and nature data availability. EBRD clients and consultants will be crucial to this new effort, and can enhance their reputation and impact via their participation.<br class="mb-4">The primary audience for this webinar is EBRD clients and consultants who conduct biodiversity impact assessments for projects financed by the Bank. However, others who are considering a similar biodiversity data sharing approach or who simply want to learn more about using the GBIF platform may also find the content beneficial.<br class="mb-4">The upcoming webinar will go over the practical steps of biodiversity data sharing with GBIF, including the types of data that can be published through the platform, the process of becoming a GBIF data publisher, where to find support for data publishing, and a live demonstration of the data upload process using theIntegrated Publishing Toolkit <> (IPT).<br class="mb-4">Representatives from relevant GBIF country nodes will be present to answer common questions and make first-hand connections. The full agenda is noted below. This event is part ofData4Nature <>, a sub-initiative by GBIF to encourage international financial institutions to share biodiversity data generated during project impact assessments.<br class="mb-4"> Register <https://events.teams.microsoft.com/event/946c3ed9-6c1a-4be9-a9ae-f34dce9d7642@172f4752-6874-4876-bad5-e6d61f991171><br class="mb-4">We encourage you to review the EBRD's GBIF data upload guidance <https://www.ebrd.com/documents/environment/technical-guidance-for-ebrd-clients-on-uploading-biodiversity-data-to-the-global-biodiversity-information-facility-.pdf>, which is the cornerstone of the Bank’s new data sharing initiative and will provide the focus for the webinar.<br class="mb-4">Agenda<br class="mb-4"> * Opening: Recap of EBRD’s GBIF data sharing initiative  * What is GBIF and what kinds of data can be published on GBIF?  * How to become a GBIF data publisher?  * Data publishing on the Integrated Publishing Toolkit (IPT)—an introduction and live demo  * Benefits of becoming a data publisher  * Q&A and closing Email questions, comments or feedback to Marshall Geck <> or Chenxi Zhu <>

title: Data Use Club practical sessions: accessing and downloading species information
description: Many users come to GBIF.org <https://www.gbif.org/> in order to access occurrence records (the observation or collection of a specimen at a given time and place). They can also access information about species: their scientific names, taxonomy, and associated data like vernacular names or whether they are invasive in a given country.<br class="mb-4">This practical session will focus on accessing and downloading information about taxa. The first part will focus on the data from GBIF with an overview of what is available on the website and what can be accessed via the API. The second part will focus on accessing data fromChecklistBank <https://www.checklistbank.org/>.<br class="mb-4">If you are interested in the topic and would like to get the most out of the session, we encourage you to check our previousData Use Club <> webinars on the GBIF Backbone taxonomy <> and our introduction to the GBIF API <>.<br class="mb-4">Speakers<br class="mb-4"> * Markus Döring <https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7757-1889>  * Marie Grosjean <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2685-8078>  * Thomas Stjernegaard Jeppesen <https://orcid.org/0000-0003-1691-239X>  * Cecilie Svenningsen <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9216-2917>  Register <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZAodOuhpjIqGdeuXogGld0NIbvNdnvTjWjX> <br class="mb-4">Email questions, comments or feedback to datause@gbif.org <mailto:datause@gbif.org>

title: Capacity enhancement workshop on biodiversity data mobilisation and use in support of sustainable development in West Africa
description: Organized as part of the Capacity Enhancement Support Programme project "Enhancing capacity to mobilize and use biodiversity data to support sustainable development in West Africa" (CESP2020-005) <https://www.gbif.org/project/ImAtw3uVGVpjrpiYHAxvD/enhancing-capacity-to-mobilize-and-use-biodiversity-data-to-support-sustainable-development-in-west-africa>, this workshop was held at the University of Ghana and aimed to enhance participants' knowledge and skills in utilizing biodiversity for sustainable development.<br class="mb-4">The workshop drew 18 participants from diverse backgrounds, including academia, forestry, and environmental sectors. The workshop spanned five days and consisted of presentations, practical sessions, and exercises.

title: 4th Global Soil Biodiversity Conference
description: Expanding on the Global Soil Biodiversity Initiative <https://www.globalsoilbiodiversity.org/>'s previous events (GSBI), the 4th Global Soil Biodiversity Conference in Victoria, Canada will convene the world’s leading experts in this interdisciplinary field of soil biodiversity science to present and discuss recent advances addressing the urgency of meeting global challenges which link to human, animal and plant health and a more sustainable world.<br class="mb-4">The conference will be the top meeting for all scientists, technologists, experimentalists and modellers, students and practitioners working on any aspects of soil biodiversity science and its linkages to the functioning of our global biosphere. The conference will provide the latest updates on soil biodiversity research and knowledge for scientists, policy makers, regulators, environmental agencies, conservationists, land-use managers and other stakeholders in the sustainable use and conservation of soil biodiversity.<br class="mb-4">Visit website <https://www.globalsoilbiodiversity.org>

title: WEBINAR POR EL DIA MUNDIAL DE LA VIDA SILVESTRE 2024 Conectividad Digital para la Conservacion de la Biodiversidad
description: <br class="mb-4">Desde el 2013, cada 3 de marzo, se celebra el Día Mundial de la Vida Silvestre con el objetivo de crear conciencia sobre el incalculable valor de la fauna y flora silvestres para la naturaleza y el bienestar humano, la urgente necesidad de combatir los delitos contra el medioambiente y la disminución de especies a causa de las actividades humanas, lo que acarrea consecuencias negativas de gran alcance tanto en el ámbito económico, medioambiental y social. En 2024, esta fecha propone explorar la innovación digital y destacar cómo las tecnologías y los servicios digitales de conservación pueden impulsar la conservación de la vida silvestre, el comercio sostenible y legal de la vida silvestre y la coexistencia entre los seres humanos y la vida silvestre, ahora y para las generaciones futuras en un mundo cada vez más conectado. En este sentido, el Ministerio del Ambiente, Agua y Transición Ecológica de Ecuador (MAATE) en coordinación con Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS), convocan al webinar "Conectividad Digital para la Conservación de la Biodiversidad", en el que participarán cuatro panelistas, usuarios de aplicaciones tecnológicas, quienes compartirán sus experiencias de uso y manejo de estas herramientas digitales enfocadas en la conservación de la naturaleza. Esta actividad es posible en el marco de los proyectos “Paisaje Jaguar” financiado por el Fondo para el Medio Ambiente Mundial (GEF), en alianza con el Programa Mundial de la Vida Silvestre (GWP), del Banco Mundial, y “Conservando Juntos” implementado en alianza con la Agencia de los Estados Unidos para el Desarrollo Internacional (USAID).<br class="mb-4"> Register <https://zoom.us/meeting/register/tJMkdu-gqj4jG9VZ5C-0hJ2UawIKyhItCtcB#/registration>

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: April 2024
description: The topic for the next Technical Support Hour for nodes is A general introduction to GBIFs technical documentation. Last year the GBIF Secretariat released the first version of the technical documentation and work is ongoing to improve and enrich the documentation. We will give you an introduction to what information is already accessible.<br class="mb-4">Note that we are switching to summer time in Denmark and therefore the session has moved one hour ahead.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZUpf-GqqD8jE9ae6KKyPnpfl97YP_-s9QFU> <br class="mb-4">We will be happy to answer any question relating or not to the topic. Please feel free to post questions in advance onthe discourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/a-general-introduction-to-gbifs-technical-documentation-gbif-techincal-support-hour-for-nodes/4335> or writehelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.

title: Global Registry of Scientific Collections (GRSciColl) community call
description: Join us for an update on the Global Registry of Scientific Collections <https://scientific-collections.gbif.org/>.<br class="mb-4">In this community call we will discuss the progress of the GRSciColl roadmap implementation <https://scientific-collections.gbif.org/road-map>.<br class="mb-4">Agenda<br class="mb-4"> * Review of the data schema: output of the survey, changes being implemented and mapping to Latimer Core  * Support structured collection descriptors: proposed implementation and examples  * Q&A and Discussion  Register <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZYudeuqrDooE9yUXe4GSGEueV0VRYbDO4Zf>

title: Europe and Central Asia Nodes meeting 2024
description: The 16th meeting of the GBIF Europe and Central Asia nodes is hosted by the GBIF Croatia <https://www.gbif.org/country/HR/summary> 26 to 29 of May 2024 the in person and on site meeting is open to node managers from the European and Central Asia participant nodes. Nonmember countries and international organizations are invited to express their interest to join the meeting as observers.<br class="mb-4">The ECA nodes have been through an open regional process, led by Dag Endresen and Niels Raes, to select the dates and country to host the meeting. The meeting will be held in Zagreb. The selection of Croatia also reflects the wish to strengthen engagement in the Balkans and the visibility of GBIF in this relatively new GBIF Participant country.<br class="mb-4">Agenda and meeting overview <https://bit.ly/gbifeca2024><br class="mb-4">For any further information contact Dag Endresen <mailto:dag.endresen@nhm.uio.no> Nodes regional representative for Europe and Central Asia.

title: Biodiversa+ GBIF joint symposium
description: Symposium organized jointly by Biodiversa+ and GBIF, to discuss the requirements for national biodiversity monitoring hubs in the context of proposals for a European Biodiversity Observation Coordination Centre.<br class="mb-4">The symposium, which follows a similar event in Brussels in October 2022 <https://www.gbif.org/event/3HwbtLlzS7jHGYa534evEB/data-beyond-borders-collaborating-to-support-biodiversity-information-needs-in-europe-and-beyond> alongside the 29th GBIF Governing Board, will explore how GBIF national nodes can support such hubs, and discuss the need for coordination of GBIF activity at the EU level. It is held in association with a number of meetings over three days in Helsinki and Tallinn, Estonia, linked to thelaunch of 23 projects funded through the BiodivMon call <https://www.biodiversa.eu/2024/03/21/biodivmon-kick-off/>, to support transnational monitoring of biodiversity and ecosystem change.<br class="mb-4">In-person attendance is by invitation only, but virtual attendance is welcome for GBIF Heads of Delegation, Node Managers and nodes staff for Participants in the Europe and Central Region.<br class="mb-4"> Register <https://link.webropolsurveys.com/EventParticipation/EventPublic/df6b7d1a-48b0-447f-a3ed-b3854539e157?displayId=Fin3049698>

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: May 2024
description: May 1st, 2024, we will convene for the next GBIF technical support hour for nodes where the topic is how to detect and solve formatting issues in your DwC-A. The session will occur on May 1st, 2024, at 4pm CEST (UTC+2).<br class="mb-4">Publishers and nodes occasionally encounter errors that are not transparent when they try to validate their DwC-A’s with thedata validator tool <https://www.gbif.org/tools/data-validator> on GBIF.org <https://www.gbif.org/>. The errors often relate to issues with delimiters, special character, e.g. two double quotes (“”””) around values in one or few cells which affects interpretation of delimiters, etc. If you have any examples of weird formatting issues – please let us know and we will make sure to include it in the presentation!<br class="mb-4">We will show the validator tool and how to problem solve using a few tools to check your files.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZMpcuyprzItGd3Dgv90l4Iv8RCL-IjADgFd#/registration><br class="mb-4">We will be happy to answer any question relating or not to the topic. Please feel free to post questions in advance onthe discourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/how-to-detect-and-solve-formatting-issues-in-your-dwc-a-gbif-technical-support-hour-for-nodes/4390> or writehelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.

title: Joint regional meeting kick-off and CESP community webinar
description: Expected audience: Node Managers and Node staff<br class="mb-4">Note this webinar will be run twice to accommodate different time zones. Please register to the one that works best for you below.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event (evening CPH time) <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZctdO2rrjorGtM88sAl4CH5sniqTKUgEQWj> <br class="mb-4"> Register for the event (morning CPH time) <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZItdOivpj0uGNMe3ck6Qm0MN7NhRdHfQ7Jh> <br class="mb-4">The webinar will firstly provide updates from the Nodes Committee and GBIF Secretariat as background for regional discussions in the 2024 regional nodes meetings. These will follow the structure provided in the2024 Nodes Implementation Plan <https://docs.gbif.org/nodes-implementation-2024/en/>.<br class="mb-4">Secondly, we will discuss changes to the format of the GBIF Capacity Enhancement Support Programme <https://www.gbif.org/programme/82219/capacity-enhancement-support-programme> and encourage nodes to participate in upcoming call for proposals.<br class="mb-4">Agenda<br class="mb-4">| Topic | Speaker | | ----- | ------------------------------------------ | | Welcome address and introduction to the 2024 regional nodes meetings |Anne Sophie Archambeau <https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6902-1465>Nodes Committee Chair (15 minutes)| | Updates on the topics for regional discussions as outlined in the Nodes Implementation Plan |Melianie Raymond <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6158-8202>  Community and Capacity Manager (30 minutes) | | Question time | (15 minutes)| | Updates to the GBIF Capacity Enhancement Support Programme |Maheva Bagard LaursenProgramme Officer for Community and Capacity (20 minutes)| | Question time | (15 minutes)|

title: Unlocking Slovakias Biodiversity Through Data Publishing
description: This workshop is a part of CESP2023-005 <https://www.gbif.org/project/CESP2023-005/unlocking-slovakias-biodiversity-through-data-publishing> and is designed for researchers, data managers, and biodiversity enthusiasts who are keen to enhance their skills in data publishing and management, with a focus on biodiversity data in Slovakia.

title: Africa nodes webinar
description: GBIF is working with regional support teams in Africa, Asia, the Caribbean, Europe and Central Asia. In this webinar, the regional support team in Africa will update the Node Managers and staff within the region, highlighting their ongoing efforts. There will be a deliberate emphasis to align these efforts with the objectives of the Nodes implementation plan, as well as with the specific tasks designated for Node Managers and staff within the plan. In this way, the members will demonstrate how they are complementing nodes to effectively execute the implementation plan.<br class="mb-4">The webinar will also be an opportunity for the node managers to plan for the upcoming joint meeting of the African nodes and launch of the next phase of theBID programme <https://www.gbif.org/programme/82243/bid-biodiversity-information-for-development>.<br class="mb-4">For any further information contact the Africa regional support team <mailto:africa_support@gbif.org>.<br class="mb-4">Agenda<br class="mb-4">| Topic | Speaker | | ----- | ------------------------------------------ | |Welcome address and introduction to: (i) the regional/sub-regional webinar series (ii) Roadmap towards the regional nodes meeting & Launch of the second phase of BID programme |Jean Paul Kubwimana <https://www.gbif.org/contact-us/directory?personId=4072&group=nodesCommittee>Chairperson, regional nodes committee (Africa) (10 minutes)| | Activities of the regional support team: technical and help desk support |Tsiky Rabetrano <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1114-956X> regional support team  (15 minutes) | |Activities of the regional support team: collection mobilization for the Global Registry of Scientific Collections(GRSciColl) <https://scientific-collections.gbif.org/>|Laban Musinguzi <https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7915-3218> regional support team  (10 minutes)| | Discussion & questions | (20 minutes)| | Way forward for regional nodes meeting and subsequent webinars|Jean Paul Kubwimana <https://www.gbif.org/contact-us/directory?personId=4072&group=nodesCommittee>Chairperson, regional nodes committee (Africa) (5 minutes)|<br class="mb-4">Time: 3:00 PM in Central Africa and 4:00 PM in East Africa<br class="mb-4"> Attend the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/j/89768083406?pwd=RFIzemR5YnJXVFNweXZiVWZwRDdmZz09>

title: Arab State Workshop on Biodiversity Data
description: Agenda<br class="mb-4">| Day 1 | Topic | | ----- | --------------------------------------- | |9.00 - 10.30 | Session 1: Welcome and Introductions| |11.00 - 12.30 |Session 2: What is GBIF and what is its relevance?| |13.30 - 15.00 |Session 3: How can GBIF support countries to meet the Kunming - Montreal Biodiversity Targets?| |15.30 - 17.00 |Session 3: Continued|<br class="mb-4">| Day 2 | Topic | | ----- | --------------------------------------- | |9.00 - 10.30 | Session 4: Building community and capacity for the sharing of open biodiversity data in the Arab States| |11.00 - 12.30 |Session 4: Continued| |13.30 - 15.00 |Session 5: Developing a road map for biodiversity data for the Arab States| |15.30 - 17.00 |Session 5: Continued|<br class="mb-4">

title: International Conference on Research Infrastructures
description: The International Conference on Research Infrastructures is the major professional forum for the global research infrastructure community. ICRI 2024 will bring together policymakers, research institution leaders, facility operators, users and researchers, to discuss pressing topics of interest, trends and challenges facing research infrastructures around the world.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://icri2024.au/>

title: Latin America and Caribbean Nodes meeting 2024
description: Will be available soon Agenda and meeting overview <https://gbif.ambiente.gob.ec/nodes-meeting-2024><br class="mb-4">Contact Leslie Melisa Ojeda Cabrera <mailto:snib.guatemala@gmail.com> Nodes regional representative for Latin America and the Caribbean for any further information on the agenda.<br class="mb-4">Questions on the logistics please contact Victor Sánchez Chocho <mailto:victor.chocho@ambiente.gob.ec> Nodes regional representative deputy for Latin America and the Caribbean

title: 8th Annual Digital Data in Biodiversity Research Conference: Synthesizing & Harmonizing Data for Integrated Biodiversity Research
description: <br class="mb-4">iDigBio <https://www.idigbio.org/>, the Natural Science Collections Alliance (NSCA) <https://nscalliance.org/>, and The University of Kansas's Biodiversity Research Institute are delighted to announce the 2024 Digital Data in Biodiversity Research Conference, 29-31 May, with this edition of the conference offering both in-person and virtual participation. The overall theme for the 2024 conference will be Synthesizing & Harmonizing Data for Integrated Biodiversity Research.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://www.idigbio.org/content/digital-data-2024-synthesizing-harmonizing-data-integrated-biodiversity-research>

title: Data Use Club practical sessions: cloud computing services
description: Utilizing cloud computing services <https://techdocs.gbif.org/en/cloud-services/> can enable big data queries that are slow or impractical on a local machine. Public datasets containingsnapshots <https://www.gbif.org/occurrence-snapshots> of all GBIF-mediated occurrence data are shared each month on the Microsoft Planetary Computer (Azure), as an Amazon AWS Open Dataset, and on a public Google GCS bucket and BigQuery table.<br class="mb-4">During this practical session, GBIF Data Analyst, John Waller <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7302-5976>, will describe the snapshots and will demonstrate how to query and cite GBIF-mediated data using these cloud services.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZElc-ispz8uHNJaZDBD9Mvnzb_BLT95wKr3>

title: Open question and answer session for CESP2024 call for proposals
description: Expected audience: Node managers, Node staff and potential project partners<br class="mb-4">The GBIF Secretariat will be holding an open question and answer session in English, for persons interested in knowing more about the2024 CESP call for proposals <https://www.gbif.org/news/4XHudxoaMexjeqgdaejBBg/>.<br class="mb-4">The aim is to provide an opportunity to raise any questions about the call’s criteria and format, applying for CESP grant, as well as about the programme in general. If you are looking for partners, it is also an opportunity to seek support.<br class="mb-4">We highlight that applications for the CESP grant must be submitted by a Head of Delegation or a Node Manager, representing a currentGBIF Participant (either voting or associate) <https://www.gbif.org/the-gbif-network>. Node staff and/or potential project partners are also welcome to attend this event.<br class="mb-4">Please be informed the event will be kept open for as long as there are attendees and questions.<br class="mb-4">Note this webinar will be run twice to accommodate different time zones. Please choose the one that works best for you.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the evening session (CPH time) <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZItfu6gpjstHNCX4SsJAvdlmv04PPoJZ4N4> <br class="mb-4"> Register for the morning session (CPH time) <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZwpdOurrj8jEtUJcgFbRxI9hsSpssXQjHtK> <br class="mb-4">If you are unable to attend either of these times and have questions for us, you are always welcome to submit them toCESP@gbif.org <mailto:CESP@gbif.org>.

title: 2024 Virtual Data Mobilization Workshop for Asia
description: The GBIF Asia Regional Support Team is organizing a data mobilization workshop to address capacity needs and to promote data publication in the region. Based on theGBIF Biodiversity Data Mobilization curriculum <https://docs.gbif.org/course-data-mobilization/en/>, this workshop trains data holders in project planning, data capture, data management and data publication, with a focus on GBIF's tools and infrastructure. Participants who successfully complete the workshop receive a badge to certify the skills and expertise they acquire. The course is conducted in English.<br class="mb-4">Schedule<br class="mb-4">The workshop has three phases of activities:<br class="mb-4"> * 24–28 June: Preparatory course activities (online, self-paced)  * 1–5 July: Virtual workshop (daily Zoom sessions and online, self-paced, estimated 4 hours per day starting at 03:00 UTC, seeinfo <> below)  * 8–28 July: Certification exercises (online, self-paced) Application<br class="mb-4">Due to limited training personnel, we will only be able to accommodate 30 participants in this workshop. We hope all participants will become trainers or mentors for future workshops.<br class="mb-4">If we receive over 30 applications to participate in the training, we will select participants based on the following criteria (not in specific order):<br class="mb-4"> * Applicants that have already identified dataset(s) that they intend to publish and have cleared licensing requirements;  * Applicants that represent data holding institutions planning to publish data;  * Applicants that have plans to hold replication workshops;  * Applicants that intend to become mentors to support future workshops (advanced badge needed); The selection process will also consider geographic and thematic balance in the workshop participants.<br class="mb-4">The deadline for applying is 2 June 2024 at 23:59 UTC. All applicants will be notified on 9 June.<br class="mb-4">Apply here <http://links.gbif.org/24-asia-dm-apply> <br class="mb-4">Start times of virtual workshop in select cities:<br class="mb-4">| City | Time | Timezone | |----------------------------------------------------|-------|----------| | Seoul | 12:00 | KST | | Tokyo | 12:00 | JST | | Manila | 11:00 | PHST | | Taipei | 11:00 | CST | | Jakarta | 10:00 | WIB | | Kathmandu | 08:45 | NPT | | Mumbai | 08:30 | IST | | Islamabad | 08:00 | PKT |

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: July 2024
description: Join us for the next session of the technical support hour for GBIF nodes on July 3rd, 2024, where the topic is API SQL downloads.<br class="mb-4">Would you like to be able to generate custom summary views of GBIF occurrence data? This is now possible as an experimental feature withAPI SQL downloads <https://techdocs.gbif.org/en/data-use/api-sql-downloads> with an added bonus ofcustom functions <https://techdocs.gbif.org/en/data-use/api-sql-download-functions> that can be used to query the data. During the practical session, we will show some examples of how the API SQL downloads can be used to generate occurrence data summaries relevant for nodes and share a few recipes along the way. Please note that the feature is currently only available for preview by invited users.<br class="mb-4">We will be happy to answer any question relating or not to the topic. Please feel free to post questions in advance on thediscourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/api-sql-downloads-gbif-technical-support-hour-for-nodes/4459> or write tohelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZAlf-qsqjMrHdLvqFiTuccIBu1W0_ywNsxr>

title: 12th North American Paleontological Convention (NAPC)
description: The North American Paleontological Convention (NAPC) <https://sites.lsa.umich.edu/napc2024/> covers all branches of paleontology, including vertebrate, invertebrate, paleobotany, micropaleontology, paleo-related organic and inorganic geochemistry, paleoecology, paleoclimatology, and astrobiology. It provides a forum for exchanging research findings, defining future directions, and fostering relaxed interactions within the paleontological community at large. The meeting will feature a variety of symposia and topical sessions, varied field trips, and technical workshops.<br class="mb-4">Visit website <https://sites.lsa.umich.edu/napc2024/>

title: Webinar #2 for the Americas: OBIS-GBIF Joint Strategy and Action Plan

title: Virtual Data Use Workshop for Asia 2024
description: As part of our continuous mission to capacity development in the region, GBIF Asia Regional Support Team is organising a virtual data use workshop to share knowledge of using GBIF data infrastructure. This course is designed for individuals who work as researchers or technicians in biodiversity research or policy institutions. The instruction provided is particularly useful for those who have a need or desire to use GBIF-mediated data in their own research or analyses.<br class="mb-4">Schedule<br class="mb-4">The workshop has three sections of activities organised into two days:<br class="mb-4"> * 15 July: Section I - Darwin Core Standard and GBIF.org and Section II - Data quality<br class="mb-4"> * 16 July: Section III - Data processing and pipelines (API, automation, R)<br class="mb-4">Sessions will be held each day beginning at 06:00 UTC and will last approximately 3 hours with a 15 minute break.<br class="mb-4">Participants who attend both sessions will receive a certificate of attendance.<br class="mb-4">Participants in the workshop should possess the following skills and knowledge:<br class="mb-4"> * Basic skills in computer and internet use, and in the use of spreadsheets.  * Basic understanding of computer-based geographical and statistical analysis tools e.g. GIS and R, and may have already run analyses using these tools.  * Basic knowledge about geography and biodiversity informatics: geography and mapping concepts, basic taxonomy, and nomenclature rules.  * A good command of English. While efforts are made to provide materials in other languages, instruction/videos will be in English. Due to limited training resources, we have 20 seats available for this workshop. If we received more registrations, we will prioritise:<br class="mb-4"> * Instructors who have running curricula ready to incorporate GBIF data use materials;  * Individuals who have published or involved in publishing data through GBIF, thus equipped essential knowledge of the GBIF data chain;  * Individuals who can commit time to disseminate the knowledge learned in the workshop with partners and collaborators in your project by adapting the biodiversity data use training materials to specific contexts and languages while maintaining their instructional value. Prerequisite Introduction to GBIF <https://docs.gbif.org/course-introduction-to-gbif/en/> online course<br class="mb-4">The deadline for applying is 23 June 2024 at 23:59 UTC<br class="mb-4">Apply here <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1A2zKUbLpScnnuGnzPW-cOCMb6MaZDpBvnYOt5wLeMkU/edit><br class="mb-4">Start times of virtual workshop in select cities:<br class="mb-4">| City | Time | Timezone | |----------------------------------------------------|-------|----------| | Seoul | 15:00 | KST | | Tokyo | 15:00 | JST | | Manila | 14:00 | PHST | | Taipei | 14:00 | CST | | Jakarta | 13:00 | WIB | | Kathmandu | 11:45 | NPT | | Mumbai | 11:30 | IST | | Islamabad | 11:00 | PKT |

title: Africa region Webinar: An Overview of GBIF Data Publishing Tools
description: The GBIF Africa Regional Support Team is pleased to provide an overview of the GBIF Data Publishing Tools. This webinar will serve as an update to the latest GBIF tools for data management, and their functionalities. The aim is to help participants understand how to effectively use these tools to enhance data quality and accessibility.<br class="mb-4">If you have any questions please email them to africa_support@gbif.org <mailto:africa_support@gbif.org><br class="mb-4">We look forward to your participation in this engaging and informative session!<br class="mb-4">Agenda<br class="mb-4">1. Introduction to GBIF Data Management Tools (10 minutes)<br class="mb-4"> * A brief introduction to the suite of GBIF data management tools. 2. Demonstration of selected tools (30 minutes)<br class="mb-4"> * GBIF Data Validator: How to check and improve the quality of datasets before publishing.  * Species name matching: How to validate scientific names against the GBIF backbone.  * Brief mention & links to other tools: IPT, Name Parser, and Sequence ID Tool <https://data-blog.gbif.org/post/installations-and-hosting-solutions-explained/>. 3. Q&A Session (20 minutes)<br class="mb-4"> * Discussion and answers to questions.  Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZMtfuChrTgpH93dHjxlV4CrbeBlXDCAqH0f>

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: August 2024
description: This August session of the Technical Support Hour for Nodes, we will show you how to publish data on GBIF via theregistry API <https://techdocs.gbif.org/en/openapi/v1/registry>. This is particularly relevant for data providers who wish to automate the publishing process. The Data Product team will go through everything you need to know to get started. You canread this blog post <https://data-blog.gbif.org/post/installations-and-hosting-solutions-explained/> for some background. We will be happy to answer any question relating or not to the topic.<br class="mb-4">Please feel free to post questions in advance on the discourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/how-to-publish-data-via-the-gbif-api-gbif-technical-support-hour-for-nodes/4575> or write tohelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZ0kfu2spz4qEtanfLpjMwKahAJZ8m0SUK4c#/registration>

title: Global Registry of Scientific Collections (GRSciColl) community call
description: Join us for an update on the Global Registry of Scientific Collections <https://scientific-collections.gbif.org/> (GRSciColl).<br class="mb-4">In this community call, we will discuss the progress of the GRSciColl roadmap implementation <https://scientific-collections.gbif.org/road-map> and gather input on integrating institutional survey outputs into GRSciColl.<br class="mb-4">Agenda:<br class="mb-4"> * Update on the latest GRSciColl developments  * Discuss ideas for making institutional surveys available on GRSciColl  * Q&A session  Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZ0tf-2uqDMsGtFf0ptdvxnEFwnViFvxQTzX>

title: Biodiversity data in montane and arid Eurasia
description: This two-day symposium is jointly organized by GBIF <https://www.gbif.org/> and by theInstitute of Zoology of Republic of Kazakhstan <https://zool.kz/eng/main-page/> with the support from the Scientific Society Tethys <http://tethys.pro/> and Kazakhstan Programme Committee for the UNESCO Program <https://www.kazmab.kz/index.php/en/> "Man and the Biosphere <https://www.unesco.org/en/mab>" (MAB).<br class="mb-4">Download programme <><br class="mb-4">Meeting goals<br class="mb-4"> * Raise awareness of GBIF as an international network and data data infrastructure for biodiversity  * Highlight key benefits for science and policy, progress on national participation, and regional growth and development of the network  * Clarify and discuss institutional and individual benefits of FAIR and open data for biodiversity  * Increase the number of institutions registered as GBIF publishers and listed inGlobal Registry of Scientific Collection <https://www.scientific-collections.gbif.org> (GRSciColl)  * Demystify key concepts, standards, tools and processes  * Encourage data publishing, access and citation Agenda outline<br class="mb-4">Joining GBIF<br class="mb-4"> * Introductions Speeches and opening remarks  * GBIF global relevanceWhat is GBIF, and why does it matter? GBIF for science and policy at national, regional and global scales  * GBIF in Eurasia Introduction to GBIF's regional activities through presentations from guest speakers, as this work requires a community who promote the sharing and use of biodiversity data as well as technical expertise and support. The session will explore how GBIF aspires to support national, institutional and individual capacity needs, with a focus on Central Asia and on adjacent states. Participating in GBIF<br class="mb-4"> * Accessing GBIF for scientific and practical useMillions of biodiversity data records are freely and openly available online for use and application. The session will cover key avenues for benefiting from open data as well as best practices around data access, data use, and data citations.  * Managing and publishing biodiversity dataProactive efforts are required to standardize and publish open biodiversity data and make it accessible and citable. How does one start, either as an organization or an individual? This session will outline best practices, standards, tools and other solutions to make managing and sharing data easy and efficient. Languages and format<br class="mb-4">The symposium’s working languages are English and Russian, and the event will take place within live on-site sessions only (remote or hybrid attendance is not possible).<br class="mb-4">Questions<br class="mb-4"> * For information on the the agenda, contact central-asia@gbif.org <mailto:central-asia@gbif.org> or Marina A. Chirikova <mailto:marina.chirikova@zool.kz>  * For further information on accommodation and logistics, contact Ilya A. Zhuravlev <mailto:Iliya.zhuravlev@zool.kz> Follow-on event: BioDATA Advanced workshop<br class="mb-4">A satellite workshop organized by BioDATA Advanced <https://www.nhm.uio.no/english/research/projects/biodata-advanced/> led by University of Oslo <https://www.nhm.uio.no/english/> will follow on 20-22 November 2024 in Almaty, Kazakhstan.<br class="mb-4">Those who wish to attend this workshop must complete a separate registration for that event on theBioDATA Advanced project page <https://www.nhm.uio.no/english/research/projects/biodata-advanced/activities/2024-11-working-with-biodiversity-data.html>.<br class="mb-4">Travel<br class="mb-4">Limited financial support for travel and accommodation costs will be available; those interested in attending may request this through the expression of interest form.<br class="mb-4">Those interested in attending both the symposium and the BioDATA Advanced workshop must 1) take into account symposium and workshop dates and 2) wait for registration confirmations from one or both events prior to booking tickets.<br class="mb-4">

title: 2024 Nordic Symposium for Biodiversity Across the Natural and Social Sciences
description: Applications are now open to participate in the 2024 Nordic Symposium for Biodiversity Across the Natural and Social Sciences, to be held on 22-23 October 2024 in Trondheim, Norway.<br class="mb-4">Through two days of collaborative discussion, workshops, and writing, participants will together explore one big question: How can the revolution in biodiversity data be harnessed to support research within the diverse environmental- and nature-related social sciences?<br class="mb-4">Participants will have the opportunity to contribute to peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations to share the outputs of our discussions during the Symposium.<br class="mb-4">Eligibility:<br class="mb-4"> * You conduct research in the social or natural sciences, focused on biodiversity and/or nature  * You are interested in interdisciplinary engagement across natural and social sciences  * You are based in the Nordic region  * All career stages and career paths, in and out of academia, are very welcome to apply Cost-free participation: Thanks to the support of the Nordic Board for Wildlife Research, NTNU, SLU, and the University of Iceland, we are thrilled to be able to offer attendance at no cost and to offer each participant a stipend (up to €500) to cover costs associated with participating.<br class="mb-4">To apply: Complete the application form on the Symposium website<br class="mb-4"> Apply here <https://www.nordicbiodiversitysymposium2024.no/apply-now.html> <br class="mb-4">Apply by Friday 6 September 2024 for full consideration.

title: Africa region Webinar: Best Practices for Mobilizing and Publishing Biodiversity data on GBIF
description: The GBIF Africa Regional Support Team invites you to participate in the third webinar for the region. This session aims to enlighten participants across Africa on the best practices for mobilizing and publishing data on GBIF, focusing on key aspects such as data quality, metadata, licensing, standardization, and the use of GBIF tools. The webinar will also cover overcoming challenges, sharing success stories, and strengthening community collaboration. Due to high demand from French-speaking participants, this session will be conducted in French.<br class="mb-4">We look forward to your participation in this engaging and informative session!<br class="mb-4">Agenda<br class="mb-4">| Topic | Speaker | |----------------------------------------------------|-----------| |Best Practices for Publishing Quality Data a. Data Quality: Importance of accurate, complete, and reliable data. b. Metadata: Role and key elements of comprehensive metadata.c. Licensing: Choosing appropriate licenses for data sharing. d. Data Standardization: Benefits of using standardized formats. | Tsiky RabetranoGBIF Africa Regional Support team <mailto:africa_support@gbif.org> | | |Overcoming Challenges and Building a Community a. Challenges and Solutions: Common issues in data publishing and how to address them.b. Success Stories: Examples of successful data publishing initiatives. c. Community and Collaboration: Importance of networking and collaboration within the Africa region. | Prof. Jean Cossi GangloUniversity of Abomey-Calavi & Node manager, Benin <mailto:ganglocj@gmail.com> | | | Q&A Session  a. Discussion and answers to participants' questions. | Moderator: Dr. Laban MusinguziGBIF Africa Regional Support team <mailto:africa_support@gbif.org> |<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZcocOqvqDMqGdBHGaSvo1PNTasu5K2hp6qU> <br class="mb-4">If you have any questions please email them to africa_support@gbif.org <mailto:africa_support@gbif.org>

title: Training workshop - Working with biodiversity data
description: The event is aimed at the current and aspiring coordinators of biodiversity data activities at the national and institutional levels, community managers in need of data and GBIF skills, and at the advanced students, researchers and practitioners whose studies and work involve generation and use of open biodiversity data.<br class="mb-4">Read more and register from the BioDATA Advanced home page <https://www.nhm.uio.no/english/research/projects/biodata-advanced/activities/2024-11-working-with-biodiversity-data.html><br class="mb-4">The workshop is a follow-up event from the two-day GBIF symposium at the same venue. <https://www.gbif.org/event/1ZSeGV24Ls8B5Z3sdmrB5S/biodiversity-data-in-montane-and-arid-eurasia>

title: Oceania Regional Nodes Meeting | Engagement meeting for BID Pacific
description: The Biodiversity Information for Development <> (BID) programme is entering a new phase (August 2024 to July, 2029) that will include actions in the Pacific region, such as capacity development workshops and calls for project proposals, aimed at standardizing and publishing biodiversity data via GBIF. The programme seeks to support and enhance a strong regional community of practice engaged in the sharing and reuse of biodiversity data, supporting scientific research, and mainstreaming biodiversity information into decision-making.<br class="mb-4">Meeting goals<br class="mb-4">The GBIF Oceania Regional Nodes Meeting and the Pacific Engagement Meeting for the Biodiversity Information for Development Programme will convene representatives from GBIF nodes, biodiversity data-holding institutions, the biodiversity research community, CBD regional support centres, and other initiatives dedicated to collecting, sharing and use of biodiversity data in the region.<br class="mb-4">The aims of these meetings are to:<br class="mb-4"> * Discuss approaches to strengthening the GBIF Oceania-Pacific community with those currently engaged in activities related to open biodiversity data.  * Share regional progress updates and best-practices.  * Identify key regional capacity and information needs to inform the development of the upcoming BID call for data mobilization proposals in the region.  * Identify opportunities for synergies between existing and upcoming regional initiatives and the BID programme, such as supporting or participating in related training efforts, encouraging data sharing through regional programmes, and identifying potential data flows to enhance the use of  * data mobilized through BID.  * Encourage broad participation in the calls for proposals, including applicants, reviewers, mentors, trainers, and partners. Audience<br class="mb-4">This event will be attended by representatives of:<br class="mb-4"> * GBIF nodes and Heads of Delegation in Oceania  * Representatives of other relevant regional initiative  * Representatives of selected institutions that have been involved in the BID programme Contact  Peggy Newman  <mailto:Peggy.Newman@csiro.au>, Nodes regional representative for Oceania, orAaron Wilton  <mailto:wiltona@landcareresearch.co.nz> for any further information on the agenda.<br class="mb-4">For uestions on the logistics, please contact Meredith Mckay  <mailto:mmckay@doc.govt> or Aaron Wilton  <mailto:wiltona@landcareresearch.co.nz>.<br class="mb-4"><br class="mb-4"> <https://www.europa.eu> This programme is funded by the European Union <http://www.europa.eu>.

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: October 2024
description: Join us for the next session of the technical support hour for GBIF nodes on October 2nd, 2024, at 4 pm CEST (UTC+2), where the topic is GBIF’s vocabulary server.<br class="mb-4">The GBIF Secretariat is transitioning its interpretation pipeline for controlled occurrence core fields fromJava enums <https://github.com/gbif/gbif-api/tree/dev/src/main/java/org/gbif/api/vocabulary> to a more dynamicvocabulary server <https://registry.gbif.org/vocabulary/search>. This change will facilitate the translation of vocabulary concepts into multiple languages and shift the management of vocabularies from a rigid, hard-coded system to a flexible, community-driven platform. During this session, we will give an overview of the role and benefits of vocabularies within the GBIF framework.<br class="mb-4"> Register  <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZEvc-qorDopGNJsNasCCHOGpPpwtCyiqaUg> <br class="mb-4">Please feel free to post questions on the discourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/gbifs-vocabulary-server-gbif-technical-support-hour-for-nodes/4637> or write tohelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.

title: Africa region Webinar: Introduction to flags and issues in GBIF datasets
description: The next Africa region webinar will take place September 13 3:00-4:00 PM Central Africa Time / 4:00-5:00 PM East Africa Time.<br class="mb-4">GBIF identifies common data quality problems and labels them issues and flags to records with common data quality problems. Prior knowledge of these issues and flags is important to data publishers and users. The GBIF Africa Regional Support Team invites you to participate in the fourth regional webinar. This session aims to enlighten participants across Africa on the flags and issues in data to improve quality of published data and improve user experience.<br class="mb-4">If you have any questions please email them to africa_support@gbif.org <mailto:africa_support@gbif.org><br class="mb-4">We look forward to your participation in this engaging and informative session!<br class="mb-4"> Register <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZ0lc-yopzIiHdMgJOL1TNJdlBfqupNZZIrh> <br class="mb-4">Agenda<br class="mb-4">1. Introduction to flags and issues Laban Musinguzi GBIF Africa Regional Support team <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1114-956X><br class="mb-4">2. Identifying flags and issues in published datasets Tsiky Rabetrano GBIF Africa Regional Support team <https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7915-3218><br class="mb-4">3. Q&A Session Discussion and answers to questions.

title: Course on Open, Reproducible and Transparent Science in Ecology
description: Do you want to gain new skills in data management, making your data FAIR, and your workflows reproducible? Do you want training in open-source tools such as GitHub and R that can be used to achieve this?<br class="mb-4">This course is organised by Living Norway in collaboration with the University of Bergen, GBIF Norway, Nord University, NINA, NTNU, NMBU, and UIO.<br class="mb-4">Students will be introduced to open science, data management, data repositories/databases, data standards (e.g. FAIR, CARE), best practise and reproducible workflows (e.g. data curation, analysis, GitHub, reporting results). We will invite experts to give lectures on these topics and provide hands-on training that gives the students opportunities to practise new skills. We will provide examples, but also encourage students to bring their own data and problems to work on.<br class="mb-4">Application deadline: 15th of September 2024<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://www.uib.no/en/rg/EECRG/171658/open-reproducible-and-transparent-science-ecology>

title: IUCN ROWA 10th Regional Conservation Forum
description: The RCF aims to provide IUCN Members (governments, NGOs, indigenous peoples’ organizations) with a platform to engage with each other, discuss and debate key conservation issues, and prepare for effective program planning and membership business. It also serves as an opportunity to initiate discussions on regional participation in the next IUCN Congress 2025. Additionally, the RCF contributes to strengthening knowledge and networking for biodiversity conservation in the region.

description: Meeting goals<br class="mb-4">The Africa nodes meeting aims to:<br class="mb-4"> * Strengthen the GBIF Africa community  * Provide a forum for GBIF nodes in Africa and the GBIF Secretariat to share latest updates and best practices  * Showcase the relevance of GBIF data across a broad range of use cases  * Identify key regional capacity and information needs to inform the development of the upcomingBiodiversity Information for Development <> (BID) call for proposals in the region  * Identify and explore opportunities for synergies between BID and any existing or upcoming regional-scale initiatives related to biodiversity data training, mobilization or other activities  * Encourage participation in the calls for proposals by project applicants and reviewers, mentors, trainers and other partners Audience<br class="mb-4">This event will be attended by representatives of:<br class="mb-4"> * GBIF nodes in Africa  * Relevant regional initiatives and networks  * Selected institutions previously involved in the BID programme Contact  Jean Paul Kubwimana  <mailto:jkubwimana@arcosnetwork.org> Nodes regional representative for Africa for any further information on the agenda.<br class="mb-4">Questions on the logistics please contact Luke Jimu <mailto:jimaldino@yahoo.com><br class="mb-4"><br class="mb-4"> <https://www.europa.eu> This programme is funded by the European Union <http://www.europa.eu>.

title: ICTMM2024: The 21st International Congress for Tropical Medicine and Malaria
description: The 21st International Congress for Tropical Medicine and Malaria (ICTMM) is one of the largest tropical medicine conferences in the world, bringing together thousands of researchers, experts, policy-makers, stakeholders and international authorities in the field of tropical medicine and malaria.<br class="mb-4">GBIF will participate in the Congress as an exhibitor and with an oral presentation in the One Health Session<br class="mb-4">The booth will be located on floor 2, to the right of the entrance and the presentation titled “The importance of FAIR data in vector research” will be given byPaloma Shimabukuro <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5114-953X>.<br class="mb-4">Presentation Date: 22 Sept 2024 (Sunday) Session: D4-CS5 Oral Session One Health 2<br class="mb-4"> more information <https://ictmm2024.org/programme-overview/>

title: COP-16 Side Event: Establishing collaborations on science, technology and capacity building for biodiversity data between the GBIF network and CBD regional support centres
description: This GBIF-hosted side event <https://www.cbd.int/side-events/5917> will explore regional differences to data access and utilization under the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework (GBF) and explore how the regional networks ofGBIF <https://www.gbif.org/> can enable centres to meet their needs and objectives against new reporting requirements that demand improved systems for gathering and repackaging biodiversity data.<br class="mb-4">The series of presentations and discussions comprising the session will focus on:<br class="mb-4"> * Establishing a framework for collaboration between GBIF network and regional support centres for and Sustainable scaling e-up of national biodiversity facilities to more effectively deliver and influence national and regional objectives more effectively capacity-building and development and technical and scientific cooperation  * Facilitating access to and exchange of relevant technical and scientific data, information and knowledge. Innovation and technical readiness -To enhance local, national, subregional, regional and international capacities in relation to science, technology and innovation by means of human resource and institutional capacity-building and development Expected outcomes<br class="mb-4"> * Highlight the role that regional support centres will play in facilitating access to and use of biodiversity data and identify key regional needs that require urgent support  * Demonstrate how GBIF’s data infrastructure and network, data standards and enriched data models and web and cloud-based services can support the core functions of regional and subregional support centres  * Catalyse the development of new partnerships, including identification of potential funding sources, to support programmes that facilitate access to, and utilization of available scientific knowledge, information and data

title: Biospace25
description: BIOSPACE25 <https://biospace25.esa.int/> is the first international conference exclusively dedicated to the application of Satellite Remote Sensing (SRS) across the various dimensions of biodiversity, and addressing the use of Earth Observations in all realms, from terrestrial, freshwater, coastal to marine ecosystems.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://biospace25.esa.int/>

title: Understanding and monitoring insect diversity - the environmental DNA revolution
description: Insect diversity science is undergoing transformative changes thanks to the introduction of cheap and effective DNA-based methods (so-called DNA metabarcoding) for species identification. This symposium highlights the new insights into the structure of insect communities generated by these methods and the new opportunities for biodiversity monitoring that they open up! Our focus will be on the results generated by theInsect Biome Atlas project <https://www.insectbiomeatlas.org/> — funded by the Knut & Alice Wallenberg Foundation—in which the insect faunas of Sweden and Madagascar and their associated microbiomes were analyzed in some of the most ambitious inventory projects using these methods to date.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfPW9fd1c78Ht9iZzjalHATSd2lqtT7ji_JSjJglD9QopOwgg/viewform>

title: eLTER Science Conference - Towards a whole-system approach for ecosystem science
description: An international conference for advancing our understanding of ecosystems within a pan-European network of sites, platforms, researchers, and stakeholders to facilitate collaborative, inter- and transdisciplinary science including biogeoscience, biodiversity research, and social ecology (Conference programme under development).<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://elter-ri.eu/science-conference/>

title: Swedish Oikos Conference 2025
description: This will be the 42nd conference of the Swedish Oikos Society, and the sixth time it is hosted in Stockholm.<br class="mb-4">The conference will gather researchers and students from across Sweden to share ideas and discoveries in ecological research, and solutions for our changing world. We will cover a diverse range of topics, ranging from genes to ecosystems, in Sweden and beyond.<br class="mb-4">Abstract submissions will open on the 25th of October, 2024.<br class="mb-4"> Read more  <https://nordicsocietyoikos.glueup.com/event/swedish-oikos-meeting-2025-121996/>

title: Africa region Webinar: GBIF Hosted Portals: The experience of the South African Biodiversity Institute (SANBI)
description: The next Africa region webinar will take place October 30 3:00-4:00 PM (Central Africa Time) / 4:00-5:00 PM (East Africa Time) / 2:00-3:00 PM (West Africa Time).<br class="mb-4">This webinar will introduce GBIF Hosted Portals <https://www.gbif.org/hosted-portals> which are simple and customizable portals for displaying GBIF-mediated data. The hosted Portals are designed to support national, institutional, and regional biodiversity data efforts with minimal technical demands.<br class="mb-4">The session will include:<br class="mb-4"> * A presentation from the GBIF Secretariat on the hosted portal programme and its benefits.  * A case study and live demo from SANBI-GBIF (South Africa), showcasing their successful hosted portal implementation. This webinar is ideal for GBIF nodes and institutions interested in setting up their own hosted portals.<br class="mb-4">If you have any questions please email them to africa_support@gbif.org <mailto:africa_support@gbif.org><br class="mb-4">Agenda<br class="mb-4">1. Introduction to GBIF Hosted Portals GBIF Africa Regional Support team <mailto:africa_support@gbif.org><br class="mb-4">2. SANBI-GBIF Hosted Portal: Case Study and Demo Fatima Parker, SANBI-GBIF <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0004-9504><br class="mb-4">3. Q&A Session Discussion and answers to questions.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://zoom.us/meeting/register/tJ0lfuygrjojHt0oVk24tjBtTk4ypCsUizG4.>

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: November 2024
description: Join us for the next session of the technical support hour for GBIF nodes on November 6th, 2024, at 4 pm CET (please note we are switching back to standard time), where the topic is “switching GBIF’s taxonomic backbone to the extended Catalogue of Life (xCOL)”.<br class="mb-4">Catalogue of Life is preparing an extended version of the Catalogue of Life Checklist which integrates additional taxonomic and nomenclatural data sources. This includes recently described species, additional synonyms, as well as other names originating from molecular and sequence registers. In this session, we are joined by Diana Hernández and Camila Plata from COL who will describe the progress and challenges they faced when constructing xCOL. They will also show the provenance of the selected taxonomic data sources and their relevance for closing data gaps to better represent endemic species, synonyms, and less-known taxa.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZcocOugrDwuEtYyvCPs-c_5mFfitZYV-WB2#/registration><br class="mb-4">Please feel free to post questions on the discourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/switching-gbif-s-taxonomic-backbone-to-the-extended-catalogue-of-life-xcol-gbif-technical-support-hour-for-nodes/5417> or write tohelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.

title: Datathon Africa 2024 Registration
description: On November 6-8, 2024, the Datathon Africa Consortium  <https://micoda.idiv.de/v1/datathons> will organize the 2024 Datathon <https://micoda.idiv.de/v1/datathons/2024>. The Datathon brings researchers in microbial ecology together to archive and reuse local metabarcoding sequences, enhancing discoverability and reusability of regional microbial data. It gives data producers academic credit for their work and creates a valuable resource to foster biodiversity research blind spots. Crucially, the Datathon aims to stimulate synthesis research by participants using the deposited sequences<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScUd83wIi7r6pM84-ggk1Ywt7Fda4P4zh4vD5ZxVKJ-goKIoQ/viewform><br class="mb-4">

title: ESA2025 - Ecological Society of America 2025
description: The Ecological Society of America Annual Meeting is being held Aug 10-15, 2025 in Baltimore, MD. This year's meeting theme isEcology is Everywhere.<br class="mb-4"> more information  <https://www.esa.org/baltimore2025/>

title: How to Package YouR Functions: From Standalone to R Packages (B-Cubed workshop)
description: <br class="mb-4">This workshop focuses on the most critical aspects of moving from standalone functions to an R package. It prioritizes hands-on experience while providing essential theoretical knowledge.<br class="mb-4">The workshop allows participants to:<br class="mb-4"> * Understand the basics of R packages  * Learn the practical steps of creating a package  * Get hands-on experience in package development  * Provide best practices and references for self study Given the time constraint, some topics have been condensed.<br class="mb-4">Be sure to have the following software tools installed:<br class="mb-4"> * R (preferably 4.0 or higher) <https://www.r-project.org/>  * RStudio <https://posit.co/downloads/>  * R packages: devtools <https://devtools.r-lib.org/>, roxygen2 <https://roxygen2.r-lib.org/index.html>, usethis <https://usethis.r-lib.org/>, testthat <https://testthat.r-lib.org/>, pkgdown <https://pkgdown.r-lib.org/> Agenda:<br class="mb-4">| Topic | | Time | |------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------| |Introduction | - Why packaging functions in R  - Overview of necessary tools: R, RStudio, devtools, roxygen2, testthat, pkgdown | 15 minutes | |R Package Essentials | - Structure of an R package  - Key components: description, NAMESPACE, R/, man/ | 20 minutes | | Create Your First Package | - Setting up a new package project in RStudio  - Update the description file  - Moving functions into the package structure  - Writing documentation with roxygen2  - Using devtools functions: document(), check(), build(), install()  - Addressing common errors and warnings | 40 minutes | | Testing | - Why test? - Unit-tests with testthat and devtools function test()  - Key expectations  - Test file structure | 20 minutes | | Building a documentation website | - Structure of a documentation website - Use pkgdown package | 10 minutes | | Q&A and Best Practices | - Resources for good package development - Q&A session | 15 minutes |<br class="mb-4">For any questions on the agenda contact  Damiano Oldoni  <mailto:damiano.oldoni@inbo.be> Research Software Developer at the Research Institute for Nature and Forest <https://www.vlaanderen.be/inbo/en-gb/homepage/>,Open science lab for biodiversity <https://oscibio.inbo.be/>.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZIqf-msqD8rG9CCDtrh1CuWfElKGo48ZTzA> <br class="mb-4">This workshop is part of the B-Cubed project's educational series <https://b-cubed.eu/>. B-Cubed is standardising access to biodiversity data, empowering policymakers to proactively address the impacts of biodiversity change. GBIF is a key partner of the project. B-Cubed (Biodiversity Building Blocks for policy) receives funding from the European Union’s Horizon Europe Research and Innovation Programme (ID No 101059592).

title: GBIF Metabarcoding Data Toolkit community call
description: GBIF nodes participating in the Metabarcoding Data Programme are invited to this initial community call to learn about functionalities of theMetabarcoding Data Toolkit (MDT) <https://www.gbif.org/news/3gm3lJaUQgTKZJRm6TiBff/gbif-nodes-invited-to-join-pilot-for-dna-metabarcoding-data-on-biodiversity> and discuss effective engagement with data holders. Attendees will share strategies, early feedback on MDT use, and ideas for community-building activities to enhance collaboration and knowledge exchange.<br class="mb-4">Agenda<br class="mb-4">Flexible agenda ~ 2 hours with short break<br class="mb-4">| Topic |Duration| |--------------------------------------------------------|----------| |Round of brief introductions | 10 min | | Introduction to DNA Metabarcoding Biodiversity Data | 10 min | | Demonstration of the MDT (incl Q&A)  - Justification/Reasoning - Data Templates - Data Processing - MDT Administration | 60 min | | Q&A on Tool Usage | 10 min | | Feedback from Early Usage (Node Perspectives) | 10 min | | Resources and Materials | 10 min | | Plans for Engaging Data Holders (Node Discussion) | 10 min | | Final Q&A | 10 min |<br class="mb-4">This event is by invitation only. For any questions about this community call please write to dna@gbif.org <mailto:dna@gbif.org>

title: Strengthening Capacity in the Publication of Biodiversity Data
description: The objective of the workshop is to strengthen the capacities of biological collection teams and national organizations interested in sharing national data on biodiversity through the GBIF national node, the Uruguayan Biodiversity Information System (SIBUy).

title: Global Registry of Scientific Collections (GRSciColl) community call
description: Join us for an update on the Global Registry of Scientific Collections <https://scientific-collections.gbif.org> (GRSciColl).<br class="mb-4">In this community call, we will discuss our road map for 2025 which will focus on improving the GRSciColl content and build a stronger community. Come and listen to our ideas and give us your feedback. We are looking forward to seeing you there!<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZEscumqrTspEtUdT70bt6xiRm3UfhEF1S7_>

title: Data Use Club seminar: 2024 Graduate Researchers Award winners
description: Join us for the December Data Use Club <> to hear about the research of the two 2024GBIF Graduate Researchers Award <> winners. The Graduate Researchers Award (formerly Young Researchers Award) is an annual scholarship programme that promotes and encourages innovation in biodiversity-related research using data shared through the GBIF network. Since bestowing its first awards in 2010, the programme has recognized outstanding achievements in original biodiversity research by more than two dozen Master’s and PhD students around the world.<br class="mb-4">2024 Graduate Researcher Award recipients<br class="mb-4">Ross Stewart <https://www.gbif.org/news/66bStovbp8R5IpWK0A8asc/south-african-student-ross-stewart-wins-2024-gbif-graduate-researchers-award>, South African PhD candidate from theUniversity of Johannesburg <https://www.uj.ac.za/>, will present his research which combines DNA barcoding data on flying insects with phenological data on flowering plants to explore how climate change may be changing the timing of interactions between these species across South Africa.<br class="mb-4">Paola Monguilod Brun <https://www.gbif.org/news/1WjwS621Kj7p8p7OzglC33/spanish-student-paola-monguilod-brun-wins-2024-gbif-graduate-researchers-award>, Spanish Masters student fromUniversity of Zaragoza <https://www.unizar.es/university-zaragoza>, will present her research which investigates how climate change is intensifying the risks posed by invasive alien species (IAS) to human health.<br class="mb-4">Comments and questions can be addressed to datause@gbif.org <mailto:datause@gbif.org>. This event will be recorded and the recording made available in the week after the event.<br class="mb-4">Register now <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZUodempqD8rGNykAgbhWATFbSnlhSQI8pNz>

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: December 2024
description: Join us for an end-of-year special technical support hour for GBIF nodes on December 4th, 2024, at 4 pm CET, where we will cover some of the more curious cases and questions we have received in helpdesk, during the last year. We will show examples and provide tips and tricks on how to deal with strange questions and give you the top 5 of the most common questions or feedback we have received.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZwocumppz0oGdEHngEa4u-yqP_QPOHrYLBG#/registration><br class="mb-4">We will be happy to answer any question relating or not to the topic and welcome your input on some of the stranger things you have had to deal with a node staff. Please feel free to post questions in advance on thediscourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/end-of-year-special-2024-gbif-technical-support-for-nodes/5499> or writehelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.

title: BID engagement meeting for Latin America and the Caribbean
description: The Biodiversity Information for Development <> programme (BID) is entering a new phase (August 2024–July 2029) that will include actions in the Latin America and Caribbean region, such as capacity development workshops and calls for project proposals, aimed at standardizing and publishing biodiversity data via GBIF. The programme seeks to support and enhance a strong regional community of practice engaged in the sharing and reuse of biodiversity data, supporting scientific research, and mainstreaming biodiversity information into decision-making.<br class="mb-4">Meeting goals<br class="mb-4">The BID engagement meeting for Latin America and the Caribbean will convene representatives from biodiversity data-holding institutions, the biodiversity research community, CBD regional support centres, and other initiatives dedicated to collecting, sharing and use of biodiversity data in the region.<br class="mb-4">The aims of these meetings are to:<br class="mb-4"> * Discuss approaches to strengthening the community with those currently engaged in activities related to open biodiversity data.  * Identify key regional capacity and information needs to inform the development of the upcoming BID call for data mobilization proposals in the region.  * Identify opportunities for synergies between existing and upcoming regional initiatives and the BID programme, such as supporting or participating in related training efforts, encouraging data sharing through regional programmes, and identifying potential data flows to enhance the use of data mobilized through BID.  * Encourage broad participation in the calls for proposals, including applicants, reviewers, mentors, trainers, and partners.  Register for the event <https://zoom.us/meeting/register/tJIqcOmoqD0jGNElY_zh_8H9XunSJ1s4qkmM> <br class="mb-4">For any further information on the agenda contact our regional support team for Latin America and CaribbeanAnabela Plos <mailto:lac_support@gbif.org> and Leonardo Buitrago <mailto:lac_support@gbif.org>, or Sanja Novakovikj <mailto:snovakovikj@gbif.org>, GBIF programme administrator for Community and Capacity.<br class="mb-4"><br class="mb-4"> <https://www.europa.eu> This programme is funded by the European Union <http://www.europa.eu>.

title: Africa region Webinar: Exploring Capacity-Building Opportunities in Biodiversity Data Management and Use
description: The next Africa region webinar will take place December 13 3:00-4:00 PM Central Africa Time / 4:00-5:00 PM East Africa Time.<br class="mb-4">This webinar will explore key initiatives aimed at strengthening skills and knowledge in biodiversity data management and use. Participants will discover opportunities such as the GBIF Data Use Club, Data Camp, and the Mentors and Volunteers List, designed to support knowledge sharing, capacity building, and personal professional growth. This session is important for new and experienced data publishers, researchers, and institutions eager to enhance their capabilities to contribute to biodiversity informatics.<br class="mb-4">Agenda<br class="mb-4">1. Introduction to capacity-building initiative & opportunitiess Quick overview of capacity building initiatives<br class="mb-4">2. Personal experiences with some of the initiatives Highlighting experiences after engagement and participation in some of the capacity building initiatives.<br class="mb-4">3. Q&A Session Addressing questions and discussing future steps for involvement.<br class="mb-4">If you have any questions please email them to africa_support@gbif.org <mailto:africa_support@gbif.org><br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://zoom.us/meeting/register/tJcvduGvqzItGNJN5Z2i5NALCGX8xr3EhDjD>

title: BioDT School and Hackathon
description: Join us for the BioDT School and Hackathon and become the pioneer of the Digital Twins Research!<br class="mb-4">We are excited to invite you to the BioDT School and Hackathon, which will take place from March 3-7, 2025, at the heel of Italian Peninsula – in the city of Lecce, Italy.<br class="mb-4">This unique event is designed for students, early-career researchers, and professionals interested in unlocking skills in digital modelling, and interested in latest innovation practices in biodiversity. Whether you are new to the concept of Digital Twins or looking to deepen your knowledge, this is the perfect opportunity to engage with leading experts and learn how digital twins are developed, especially through the lenses of BioDT use cases.<br class="mb-4">read more <https://biodt.eu/events/bioDT-school-hackathon>

title: SPNHC 2025
description: The Society for the Preservation of Natural History Collections SPNHC <https://spnhc2025.ku.edu/> will host its 40th annual meeting in Lawrence, Kansas, USA, from May 27–31, 2025. The event will center around the theme Sustainable Futures: Challenges and Opportunities for Modern Collections.<br class="mb-4"> read more <https://spnhc2025.ku.edu/>

title: GEO Global Forum
description: The inaugural GEO Global Forum in 2025 will be a premier global event to inspire all elements of our society – from Ministers and global leaders to citizens – to harness Earth Intelligence to empower informed and ambitious actions to ensure food security, restore ecosystems, prevent disasters, and confront the triple planetary crisis, transforming the Sustainable Development Goals into an achievable reality.<br class="mb-4">At the heart of the week, GEO-20 Plenary will include a Ministerial Segment and serve as the event’s centerpiece, where the GEO community will mark three key milestones in our journey:<br class="mb-4"> * The launch, through of the first GEO Global Forum, of a dynamic platform for advancing Earth Intelligence for all.  * The celebration of the GEO's 20th anniversary, marking two decades of multilateral collaboration, innovation, and impact.  * The adoption of the Post-2025 Strategy Implementation Plan aimed to that must deliver achieve the ambitious goals of GEO’s Post-2025 Strategy  Read more  <https://earthobservations.org/events/geo-global-forum-2025>

title: XIII Latin American Congress of Botany Cuba 2025
description: The XIII Congreso Latinamericano de Botánica will have its next edition in Havana, Cuba. Bringing together Latin American colleagues, it is expected that this meeting will increase relations between professionals in the region, both in terms of collections, morphoanatomical and genetic studies, as well as collection management systems and publication of biodiversity data.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://botanica-alb.org/congreso-cuba-2025/>

title: Open question and answer session for CESP2025 call for proposals
description: Expected audience: Node managers, Node staff and potential project partners<br class="mb-4">The GBIF Secretariat will be holding an open question and answer session in English, for persons interested in knowing more about the2025 CESP call for proposals <https://www.gbif.org/news/1ehSrAN20UAGOEAgfINr5E/call-for-proposals-for-2025-capacity-enhancement-support-programme>.<br class="mb-4">The aim is to provide an opportunity to raise any questions about the call’s criteria and format, applying for CESP grant, as well as about the programme in general. If you are looking for partners, it is also an opportunity to seek support.<br class="mb-4">We highlight that applications for the CESP grant must be submitted by a Head of Delegation or a Node Manager, representing a currentGBIF Participant <https://www.gbif.org/the-gbif-network>. Node staff and/or potential project partners are also welcome to attend this event.<br class="mb-4">Please be informed the event will be kept open for as long as there are attendees and questions.<br class="mb-4">Note this event will be run twice to accommodate different time zones. Please choose the one that works best for you.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the 09:00 session (CPH time) <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZ0udeCgqDwoHd2q4PWFy_87Y4Vsdh8l0efM> <br class="mb-4"> Register for the 17:00 session (CPH time) <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZwkdeirrDotH92FgaFty2j98zqKnDjE9SCh> <br class="mb-4">If you are unable to attend either of these times and have questions for us, you are always welcome to submit them toCESP@gbif.org <mailto:CESP@gbif.org>.

title: 2025 Virtual Data Mobilization Workshop for Asia
