description: The GBIF Asia Regional Support Team is hosting a data mobilization workshop to address capacity needs and to promote data publication across the region.<br class="mb-4">The virtual workshop will be conducted in February 2025, and will be based on theGBIF Biodiversity Data Mobilization curriculum <https://docs.gbif.org/course-data-mobilization/en/>.<br class="mb-4">The aim of the workshop is to train data holders in project planning, data capture, data management and data publication, with a focus on GBIF's tools and infrastructure. Participants who successfully complete the workshop receive a badge to certify the skills and expertise they acquire.<br class="mb-4">Schedule<br class="mb-4">The workshop will be conducted in English language across three phases:<br class="mb-4"> * 3–7 February: Preparatory course activities (online, self-paced).  * 10-14 February: Virtual workshop (daily Zoom sessions and online, self-paced, estimated 4 hours per day).  * 15 February - 9 March: Certification exercises (online self-paced). Application<br class="mb-4">Due to limited training personnel, we will only be able to accommodate 30 participants in this workshop. We encourage all participants to become trainers or mentors for future workshops to help inspire and share experiences with the Asian biodiversity community.<br class="mb-4">If more than 30 applications to participate in the training are received, participants will be selected based on the following criteria (in no specific order):<br class="mb-4"> * Applicants that have already identified dataset(s) that they intend to publish and have cleared licensing requirements.  * Applicants that represent data holding institutions planning to publish data.  * Applicants that have plans to hold replication workshops.  * Applicants that intend to become mentors to support future workshops (advanced badge needed). The selection process will also consider geographic and thematic balance in the workshop participants. If you have any questions please email them toasia_support@gbif.org <mailto:asia_support@gbif.org><br class="mb-4">The deadline for workshop applications is 12 January 2025 at 23:59 UTC. All applicants will be notified by 17 January 2025.<br class="mb-4">Apply here <https://bit.ly/25-asia-dm-apply> <br class="mb-4">Start times of virtual workshop in select cities:<br class="mb-4">| City | Time | Timezone | |----------------------------------------------------|-------|----------| | Seoul | 12:00 | KST | | Tokyo | 12:00 | JST | | Manila | 11:00 | PHST | | Taipei/Manila/Kuala Lumpur | 11:00 | CST | | Jakarta | 10:00 | WIB | | Kathmandu | 08:45 | NPT | | Mumbai | 08:30 | IST | | Islamabad | 08:00 | PKT |

title: LAND Community Workshop 2025
description: The LAND (Lebendiger Atlas der Natur Deutschlands) Community Workshop 2025 brings together users of theLAND portal <https://land.gbif.de/>, data curators, potential future data providers, the LAND team and other stakeholders of the biodiversity data community in Germany. Note registrations have now closed for this event.<br class="mb-4">Learn more <https://land.gbif.de/community_und_events/community_workshop_2025>

title: DiSSCo Transition Technical Workshop: DiSSCo DMP and Standards for Taxon Hypotheses
description: The workshop is primarily addressed to partners from WP3 and WP4 of DTP, members of theDiSSCo community <https://www.dissco.eu/knowledge-area/>, data custodians, and practitioners from the broader scientific community who may be interested in the topic.<br class="mb-4">Please, be aware that registration is compulsory. You can register here until January 16th, 2025.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeect4sCZabSd7jebHc1v4vSyjlooy-u4VjZ6a4uzqOMxxBWw/viewform>

title: Data Use Club Practical Sessions: Data standards & processing
description: The data available on GBIF comes from many different data providers: citizen science initiatives, museums, research teams, etc. The data are then processed and aggregated to enable anyone to access them seamlessly via the GBIF website and API.<br class="mb-4">This Data Use Club session aims to give users the tools to understand the context of the data available on GBIF and help them decide if the data is fit for their analyses.<br class="mb-4">We aim to answer the following questions by giving a brief overview of the use of data standards, the transformation and checks made by GBIF and the various data formats available.<br class="mb-4"> * How are these data shared and processed by GBIF before appearing on the search interface and API?  * What kinds of flags and checks are applied?  * How to find more information about the original data and how to access it? Hosts from the GBIF Secretariat<br class="mb-4"> * Marie Grosjean <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2685-8078>  * John Waller <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7302-5976>  * Cecilie Svenningsen <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9216-2917>  Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZYod-uurDMpG9elUZNDIihyjw4HY4d4PIFp>

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: February 2025
description: The next technical support hour for GBIF nodes will be on February 5th, 2025, at 4 pm CET, and the topic isinvestigating taxonomic issues on GBIF.org <https://www.gbif.org/>.<br class="mb-4">The taxonomy of the records published to GBIF is matched to GBIF’s taxonomic backbone to normalize the data and make records easier to find for GBIF data users. This means that publishers sometimes share a taxon name that is changed when appearing on GBIF.org. For example, a beetle record appears as a butterfly record, or the authorship is changed. We will show examples of how the taxonomy is changed, how to investigate where the source of the change comes from, and how you can provide feedback directly to the source or GBIF helpdesk.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZ0tdeiorDsoGdWvwy7Qsl5PGnghya-4VDft#/registration><br class="mb-4">We will be happy to answer any question relating or not to the topic and welcome your input on some of the stranger things you have had to deal with a node staff. Please feel free to post questions in advance on thediscourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/investigating-taxonomic-issues-on-gbif-org/5633> or writehelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.

title: GBIF Europe and Central Asia nodes meeting 2025
description: The 17th meeting of the nodes of the GBIF Europe and Central Asia region <> will take place inIreland <> from 20 to 23 May 2025. This in-person meeting is open to node managers from the region's participant nodes.<br class="mb-4">The meeting will take place on the West Campus of the South East Technological University <https://www.setu.ie/> in Carriganore, County Waterford, home of the GBIF Ireland node, theNational Biodiversity Data Centre <https://www.google.com/maps/place/National+Biodiversity+Data+Centre/@52.2526158,-7.1882514,379m/data=!3m2!1e3!4b1!4m6!3m5!1s0x4842c4edad804df3:0x24676f04efe945d!8m2!3d52.2526147!4d-7.1873669!16s%2Fg%2F124t14477?entry=ttu&g_ep=EgoyMDI1MDEwNy4wIKXMDSoASAFQAw%3D%3D>.<br class="mb-4">For any further information contact Dag Endresen <mailto:dag.endresen@nhm.uio.no>, regional node representative for Europe and Central Asia.

title: Webinar Digital data on biodiversity in the educational process and scientific research (in Russian)
description: This event emphasizes the utilization and dissemination of biodiversity data through the GBIF portal, showcasing practical experiences and methodologies in data digitization and publication.<br class="mb-4">It also highlights collaborative efforts in integrating digital biodiversity data into educational curricula and research initiatives, aligning with GBIF's mission to promote open access to biodiversity information.

title: Living Data 2025
description: This joint conference in Bogotá brings together members of our biodiversity networks, alongside hundreds of scientists, researchers, practitioners and other experts from around the world.<br class="mb-4">Come share your knowledge and experience, help us transform our understanding of the state and trends of biodiversity, and learn how together our work contributes towards conserving the living world.<br class="mb-4">The conference is conducted in Spanish and English only, but we are exploring options for interpretation services using new technologies to enhance the conference experience.<br class="mb-4"> About the event <https://www.livingdata2025.com/>

title: BioDigiCon 2025
description: The conference will showcase advances within public and federal collections, emphasizing opportunities for intra- and international collaboration and data integration across all domains of biodiversity and related sciences, including human health and food security as well as the environmental, ecological, and climate sciences.<br class="mb-4"> read more <https://www.biodigicon.org/>

title: ALA-LAs Technical Workshop
description: This workshop aims to strengthen collaboration and efficiency in Atlas of Living Australia (ALA) related developments, specifically targeting developers and managers within the Living Atlases (LAs) community. It is not an introductory or training workshop; rather, it is designed specifically for developers and teams actively maintaining and adapting biodiversity data portals based on the ALA platform.<br class="mb-4">The workshop is structured in two streams: one for developers and one for managers. It was suggested and welcomed to introduce a time frame dimension with two aspects. In the long term, the goal is to advance a common strategic framework. In the short term, with a focus on addressing concrete development issues, so developers can return home with practical solutions and approaches they can apply.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://gbif.es/en/talleres/ala-las-technical-workshop-madrid-march-2025/>

title: GBIF Metabarcoding Data Toolkit community call 2025
description: GBIF nodes participating in the Metabarcoding Data Programme are invited to the first MDT community call of 2025 to learn about latest developments and functionalities of theMetabarcoding Data Toolkit (MDT) <https://www.gbif.org/news/3gm3lJaUQgTKZJRm6TiBff/gbif-nodes-invited-to-join-pilot-for-dna-metabarcoding-data-on-biodiversity>, and discuss issues on the usage of the MDT, engagement with data holders, and other relevant aspects. Attendees will share feedback on MDT use, and ideas for community-building activities to enhance collaboration and knowledge exchange<br class="mb-4">Feel free to participate on the discourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/tags/c/data-publishing/6/metabarcoding-data>. For any questions about this community call please write todna@gbif.org <mailto:dna@gbif.org><br class="mb-4">Anyone not currently involved in the GBIF Metabarcoding Data Programme who wants to learn more can emaildna@gbif.org <mailto:dna@gbif.org> to request a Zoom link to join this call.

title: Hosted Portals Community Call
description: A community call with network members who are currently running GBIF's hosted portal service <>.<br class="mb-4">The meeting will provide updates on progress aligning GBIF.org and Hosted Portals, as well as address community feedback received prior to the meeting.<br class="mb-4">Anyone not currently involved in a hosted portal who wants to learn more can emailhostedportals@gbif.org <mailto:hostedportals@gbif.org> to request a Zoom link to join this call.

title: Africa region Webinar: DNA Data Publishing: Key Concepts and Darwin Core Terms
description: The next Africa region webinar will take place February 28 3:00-4:00 PM Central Africa Time / 4:00-5:00 PM East Africa Time.<br class="mb-4">This webinar will introduce DNA data publishing, focusing on key concepts, relevant Darwin Core terms, and best practices. We’ll explore how to format and share DNA-derived biodiversity data on GBIF.<br class="mb-4">If you have any questions please email them to africa_support@gbif.org <mailto:africa_support@gbif.org><br class="mb-4">Join us to enhance your understanding of DNA data publishing!<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://zoom.us/meeting/register/fm_ISdfORX2JPQsQoPky2A>

title: Course in Best Practices for Reference Genome Generation (SciLifeLab)
description: GBIF Sweden will participate in the upcoming SciLifeLab course “Best Practices for Reference Genome Generation”.<br class="mb-4">The course covers essential topics from project planning and sample collection to sequencing, data processing, data mobilization and deposition in open repositories.<br class="mb-4">The course is designed for junior and senior researchers utilizing reference genomes for biodiversity genetics research.<br class="mb-4">Topics<br class="mb-4"> * Nagoya Protocol & ABS requirements  * Biosafety, import permits  * Sampling and vouchering  * DNA extractions and sequencing  * Bioinformatic pipelines, metadata and FAIR  * Swedish Reference Genome Portal  * Data mobilization  Read more <https://training.scilifelab.se/events/best-practices-for-reference-genome-generation>

title: Hyper Island Project - Connecting Business with Biodiversity Data
description: In partnership with Knowit, GBIF Sweden is participating in a Hyper Island project where four students are exploring the question:<br class="mb-4">How can a partnership between Knowit and GBIF Sweden empower Nordic companies to make biodiversity data actionable and drive sustainable decision-making?<br class="mb-4">Running from January 9 to February 14, the project aims to develop communication strategies that demonstrate how Knowit’s clients in Scandinavia can utilize biodiversity data services developed by GBIF. A key objective is to support businesses in meeting their reporting obligations under the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) and, more specifically, the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS), particularly E4, which focuses on biodiversity and ecosystems.<br class="mb-4">The students will present their findings at the Swedish Museum of Natural History (Wickman Hall) on February 14 at 13:00.<br class="mb-4">Participants are welcome to attend in person or join remotely. Contact gbif@nrm.se <mailto:gbif@nrm.se> to register and get a meeting link.

title: 2nd SedaDNA Scientific Society conference
description: The conference will be preceded by workshops on the 23rd of June and followed by a post-conference excursion on 26th June.<br class="mb-4">This conference features a pre-conference workshop by Neotoma Paleoecology Database for launching a aeDNA database. There will also be opportunities to learn more about the history and current directions of the Neotoma DB, how to use Neotoma data in your own research, and how to submit your published data to be included in Neotoma.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://nordicsocietyoikos.glueup.com/event/2nd-sedadna-scientific-society-conference-125115/home.html>

title: Workshop - Capacity Building in Biodiversity Data Management and Mobilization
description: This workshop is a part of the GBIF Capacity Enhancement Support Programme <https://www.gbif.org/programme/82219/capacity-enhancement-support-programme> titledBuilding capacity within biodiversity data between Ethiopia and GBIF nodes in Sweden and Finland <https://www.gbif.org/project/CESP2024-013/building-capacity-within-biodiversity-data-between-ethiopia-and-gbif-nodes-in-sweden-and-finland><br class="mb-4">This three-day workshop aims to provide an understanding of GBIF, data management, data standards, and data mobilization. The sessions will include presentations, hands-on exercises, and discussions tailored to Ethiopian biodiversity data needs. Participants will gain insights into how to set up a national GBIF node, the importance of data ethics, and practical skills for data publishing and validation.<br class="mb-4"> workshop program  <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1XuuaYoIDhEGr045SW6_5T9Y3oqi3bnGk/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=107906763056646414410&rtpof=true&sd=true>

title: BioDT Final Event
description: The final event is divided into an internal (Day 1) and a public part (Day 2), with both parts meant for BioDT consortium members.<br class="mb-4">The first day of the event will be an internal consortium meeting intended for BioDT active project members only. During this day we will review the project progress, provide updates and discuss remaining activities for the last two months of the project (April-May 2025). We will also prepare for the upcoming final reporting.<br class="mb-4">The second day of the event day will be open for participation by external stakeholders and will include presentations both by DestinE and European Commission representatives.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://zoom.us/meeting/register/tJIqcOmoqD0jGNElY_zh_8H9XunSJ1s4qkmM>

title: 2025 Virtual Data Mobilization Workshop for Africa
description: The GBIF Africa Support Team is organizing a data mobilization workshop to address capacity needs and to promote data publication in the region.<br class="mb-4">This course will be based on the GBIF Biodiversity Data Mobilization curriculum <https://docs.gbif.org/course-data-mobilization/en/> and will be conducted in English.<br class="mb-4">Schedule<br class="mb-4">This workshop has three phases of activities:<br class="mb-4"> * 26 May to 4 June: Preparatory course activities (online self-paced)  * 9 to 13 June: Virtual workshop (Zoom sessions and online self-paced, estimated 4 hours per day)  * 16 June to 7 July: Certification exercises (online self-paced) Application<br class="mb-4">Due to limited training personnel, we will only be able to accommodate 30 participants in this workshop. We hope all participants will become trainers or mentors for future workshops.<br class="mb-4">If we receive over 30 applications to participate in the training, we will select participants based on the following criteria (not in specific order):<br class="mb-4"> * Applicants that have already identified dataset(s) that they intend to publish and have cleared licensing requirements.  * Applicants that represent data holding institutions planning to publish data.  * Applicants that have plans to hold replication workshops.  * Applicants that intend to become mentors to support future workshops (advanced badge needed). The selection process will also consider geographic and thematic balance in the workshop participants.<br class="mb-4">If you have any questions please email them to africa_support@gbif.org <mailto:africa_support@gbif.org><br class="mb-4">The application will close at 23:59 UTC on the 6 May 2025. The result will be announced on the 13th of May.<br class="mb-4">Apply here <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeWXUPJjWrvtra6lHgoptNKnpczIaNyVZXQ68fZMW3EP1L2Q/viewform>

title: Global Registry of Scientific Collections (GRSciColl) online training – Wrap-up meeting
description: This meeting is for participants of the Global Registry of Scientific Collections <https://scientific-collections.gbif.org/> online course who have already attended the kick-off meeting and gone through the online material.<br class="mb-4">This course aims to support the community maintaining collection data in GRSciColl. It gives an overview of the GRSciColl data structure and its relationship with GBIF data, explains the GRSciColl permissions system and presents the GRSciColl editing interface. By the end of the course, participants should be able to model and update the collection information in GRSciColl. The material of this course can be reused by the participants to organize their own online or onsite training events.<br class="mb-4">During the wrap-up meeting, participants will be able to ask questions about GRSciColl, the module that they have just completed and discuss the exercises.<br class="mb-4">Note this event will be run twice to accommodate different time zones. Please choose the one that works best for you.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the 09:00 session (CPH time) <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/8sGvTCJfRp69uRA25woYaw> <br class="mb-4"> Register for the 16:00 session (CPH time) <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/1eWZfQN7SXqMOytG71_QTg> <br class="mb-4">If you are unable to attend the meeting and would still like to participate in the online training, please email us atscientific-collections@gbif.org <mailto:scientific-collections@gbif.org>.

title: Global Registry of Scientific Collections (GRSciColl) online training – Kick-off meeting
description: If you are already an editor for the Global Registry of Scientific Collections <https://scientific-collections.gbif.org/> or if you wish to become one, you are welcome to join our online course.<br class="mb-4">This course aims to support the community maintaining collection data in GRSciColl. It gives an overview of the GRSciColl data structure and its relationship with GBIF data, explains the GRSciColl permissions system and presents the GRSciColl editing interface. By the end of the course, participants should be able to model and update the collection information in GRSciColl. The material of this course can be reused by the participants to organize their own online or onsite training events.<br class="mb-4">During the kick-off meeting, participants will be presented the training materials and exercises. The participant will then have six days to complete the three training modules before meeting again to ask questions and discuss the exercises.<br class="mb-4">Note this event will be run twice to accommodate different time zones. Please choose the one that works best for you.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the 09:00 session (CPH time) <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/jpj_LnxORtyjjJm8GafigQ> <br class="mb-4"> Register for the 16:00 session (CPH time) <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/9GNO-Q-BTiCjhbC15s9qSQ> <br class="mb-4">If you are unable to attend the meeting and would still like to participate in the online training, please email us atscientific-collections@gbif.org <mailto:scientific-collections@gbif.org>.

title: Unlocking Museum Data - A Beginners Guide to Data Standards
description: Join GBIF Sweden on May 6 for an engaging half-day workshop designed to introduce museum professionals and researchers to biodiversity data standards. This beginner-friendly session will cover essential topics, including TDWG, Darwin Core (DwC), metadata, FAIR & CARE principles, controlled vocabularies, and data interoperability.<br class="mb-4">Through expert presentations, participants will gain a foundational understanding of how standardized data enhances museum collections, supports global biodiversity research, and integrates with infrastructures like GBIF and DiSSCo. The workshop concludes with a discussion and opportunities for continued learning.<br class="mb-4">Whether you're new to biodiversity informatics or looking to strengthen your knowledge, this workshop will provide valuable insights into unlocking the potential of museum data.<br class="mb-4"> agenda <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1VPkSTeHlvjYPaE-btWdYf9xCPtpVn3nTv-49-P2zArM/edit?tab=t.0#heading=h.t864fjop1js0>

title: Workshop - AI for ecological monitoring in the Andes
description: This workshop is for Colombian and Ecuadorian researchers, scientists, and students. The aim is to bring together ecologists working with machine learning data for biodiversity science, as well as computer scientists interested in contributing to biodiversity conservation.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://wildlabs.net/event/taller-inteligencia-artificial-para-el-monitoreo-ecologico-en-los-andes-workshop-ai>

title: IX Field School on Soil Zoology and Ecology for Young Scientists
description: The School in 2025 is dedicated to modelling of soil invertebrate habitats and biodiversity. The program includes lectures and practical sessions by leading scientists in the area. The practical sessions will be divided into two levels: for beginners and those already experienced in species distribution modelling. The working languages are English and Russian.<br class="mb-4">For young colleagues, participation in the School is a step towards joining the professional scientific community, an opportunity to get introduced to modern concepts and new methods of soil ecology, to gain practical skills in habitat modelling, and to discuss their own research and difficulties with experienced colleagues. All participants will receive certificates.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://biodiversitydata.info/events/>

title: Training on Data Sharing on Vectors to Prevent and Control Vector-Borne Disease
description: This workshop is a side-event of the 5th Annual WAASuN Meeting <https://waasun.org/><br class="mb-4">This two-day workshop, jointly organized by the GBIF <> and the Special Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases (TDR) <https://tdr.who.int>, introduces early-career vector disease researchers to the practicalities of publishing disease vector data through global open-access infrastructures such as GBIF and through data papers. Experts in disease vector ecology and data mobilization and publication will present key principles and approaches in relevant topics includingFAIR (Findable Accessible Interoperable and Reusable) <https://www.go-fair.org/fair-principles/> data, data publishing with an integrated publishing toolkit (IPT), data citation, and data papers. The course will be conducted fully in-person.<br class="mb-4">The deadline for workshop application is 14 April 2025 at 17:00 UTC.<br class="mb-4"> read more <https://waasun.org/events/training-on-data-sharing-on-vectors-to-prevent-and-control-vector-borne-disease/>

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: April 2025
description: Join us for the next technical support hour for GBIF nodes on April 2nd at 4 pm CEST, where the topic is Community Metrics.<br class="mb-4">Community Metrics is a new initiative to develop new metrics, indicators and time series data products from GBIF-mediated data that can better support decision-making. The aim is to build on what is currently provided viaGBIF´s data analytics <https://www.gbif.org/analytics/global> and for this to build on work that the community has already done in this area. In the session,Andrew Rodrigues <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5468-2452> and John Waller <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7302-5976> present the idea behind the initiative and ways that the node community can actively contribute via theCommunityMetrics GitHub repository <https://github.com/gbif/CommunityMetrics>.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/hOE2-dbBRBOW1pqgjoZVEA> <br class="mb-4">We will be happy to answer any question relating or not to the topic and welcome your input on some of the stranger things you have had to deal with a node staff. Please feel free to post questions in advance on thediscourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/community-metrics/5832?u=andrewrodrigues> or writehelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.

title: Author Insight on How to Publish Vectors of Human Disease Data with GBIF and GigaByte
description: TDR, the Special Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases hosted at the World Health Organization (WHO), GBIF and GigaScience Press have just extended their third call for authors to submit data release papers on vectors of human disease for inclusion in a thematic series published in GigaByte Journal. Round three builds on the first two phases of the series, which mobilized more than 700,000 occurrence records and 890,000 specimens from more than 70 countries.<br class="mb-4">This webinar provides insight into how to submit your work to the series, with some of the authors of previous submissions presenting examples the types of work that have been published so far. And giving their perspectives of how the process of publishing a data publication is, how they working with the supporting data helpdesk to share the data with GBIF, and the feedback they have received so far from publishing their data in this manner. After this we’ll get insight from the vectors task group and data helpdesk team on their experiences and tips on submitting vectors data to GBIF. Ending with an opportunity to ask questions talking to the series editors, authors and vectors task group to ask any questions about data publishing.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://cassyni.com/events/iAC1qrycdt6HYcF9sdAUV/abstract>

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: May 2025
description: In the following technical support hour for GBIF nodes on May 7th at 4:00 pm CEST, we will introduce the first ‘Deep Dive’ session on handlingissues and flags <https://techdocs.gbif.org/en/data-use/occurrence-issues-and-flags>, and we will focus onDate issues <https://techdocs.gbif.org/en/data-use/occurrence-issues-and-flags#date-issues> for this particular session.Several date flags and issues can be associated with records when they areprocessed in GBIF pipelines <https://techdocs.gbif.org/en/data-processing/temporal-interpretation>. In this session, we will coverhow data and time are parsed <https://techdocs.gbif.org/en/data-processing/temporal-interpretation#general-date-and-time-parsing>, what fields are used forinterpreting the occurrence date <https://techdocs.gbif.org/en/data-processing/temporal-interpretation#occurrence-recorded-date>, and how users cansearch on date ranges <https://techdocs.gbif.org/en/data-processing/temporal-interpretation#searching-dates>. We will also cover relevant issues for each of these parts and how publishers can potentially fix the issue.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/ic2ev4hdQAiCvjBANiWzxQ> <br class="mb-4">Deep Dive sessions will go into detail of specific flags and issues that publishers encounter when sharing their data with GBIF and that GBIF users may use to filter their downloads. With over 60 flags and issues currently implemented, we will focus on a specific overall topic and cover critical and non-critical issues.<br class="mb-4">We will be happy to answer any question relating or not to the topic and welcome your input on some of the stranger things you have had to deal with a node staff. Please feel free to post questions in advance on thediscourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/deep-dive-date-related-issues-and-flags/5876> or writehelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.

title: Data Use Club Practical Sessions: GBIF species occurrence cubes
description: GBIF has recently enabled a simple, easy-to-use service for creating and downloading species occurrence cubes based on GBIF-mediated data. The service enables users to select their geographic, temporal and taxonomic dimensions of interest to generate customized reports summarizing occurrences in a format suitable for use in biodiversity models and indicators. Its implementation is part of Work Package 2 for B-Cubed (Biodiversity Building Blocks for Policy), led by the Research Institute for Nature and Forest (INBO).<br class="mb-4">During this session, our speakers will cover the following topics:<br class="mb-4"> * Introduction to the GBIF Cube Download Service (Andrew Rodrigues)<br class="mb-4"> * Concept of data aggregates and grids  * Data quality considerations  * User interface demonstration  * From Species Occurrence to Essential Biodiversity Variables CubesResults from the B-Cubed project (Lina Estupinan Suarez)<br class="mb-4"> * Link between Essential Biodiversity Variables (EBVs) and GBIF data  * EBV data cube derived from species occurrence to support EU policy: Birds Directive andInvasive Alien Species of Union Concern  * Resources Speakers:<br class="mb-4">Andrew Rodrigues <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5468-2452> John Waller <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7302-5976> Lina Estupinan Suarez <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2359-9496><br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/0XWC0DwkQya3H-WiHqXIig>

title: Open question and answer session for BID 2025 Latin America & the Caribbean and Pacific Region
description: The GBIF Secretariat will hold an open question-and-answer session in English, for individuals interested in participating in the 2025 BID call for proposals forLatin America & the Caribbean <https://www.gbif.org/news/psbfUTIrFlz0GBmfNfShW/2025-bid-call-for-proposals-latin-america-and-the-caribbean> andthe Pacific <https://www.gbif.org/news/7CnFmwFVne2kYDXIWzKkQY/2025-bid-call-for-proposals-pacific>.<br class="mb-4">The aim of this session is to provide an opportunity to raise any questions about the call’s scope and objectives, the various grant types, eligibility criteria, application process, evaluation criteria and the Biodiversity Information for DevelopmentBID <https://www.gbif.org/programme/82243/bid-biodiversity-information-for-development> programme more broadly.<br class="mb-4">Please note that the session will be open for up to one hour but may end earlier if all questions from attendees have been addressed.<br class="mb-4">This event will be held twice to accommodate different time zones. Please choose the session that works best for you.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the 09:00 session (CEST UTC+2)  <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/ZZtGraUlRoWwHXwyqy_4Pg> <br class="mb-4"> Register for the 21:00 session (CEST UTC+2) <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/HN1yDoaYTDWBI3cEkit-Cg> <br class="mb-4">If you are unable to attend either of these times and have questions for us, you can reach us in two ways:<br class="mb-4"> * Public forum – If your question could benefit others, we encourage you to ask it on ourpublic forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/>.  * Email – For private inquiries, you can contact us at bid@gbif.org <mailto:bid@gbif.org>.

title: Consultation on GBIF and agrobiodiversity
description: Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/0sYMlF1MQ6aWec24n2DTUA><br class="mb-4">The GBIF 2025 Work Programme <https://docs.gbif.org/2025-work-programme/en/#activity1-1> identifies agrobiodiversity as a thematic priority in need of wider consultation, building on initial discussions with domain experts in 2024.<br class="mb-4">During this 90-minute webinar, we hope to capture feedback and suggestions on a road map for engaging this thematic community, welcoming views and perspectives from staff from GBIF nodes and delegations, data publishers and users, and other experts and professionals. Please join us if you have an interest in planning processes for community-building, collaboration, content and infrastructure development related to relevant agrobiodiversity partners and services.<br class="mb-4">Background: GBIF and food <>

title: Publishing Biodiversity Data from Indigenous Communities Experiences from SiB Colombia
description: This webinar, held within the scope of the CESP project "Developing a Data Extension for Documenting Socio-Biodiversity Information" <https://www.gbif.org/project/CESP2024-015/developing-a-data-extension-for-documenting-socio-biodiversity-information> lead by SiBBr - Brazil in partnership with Argentina and Colombian nodes will present SiB Colombia’s experiences in publishing biodiversity data from indigenous communities, highlighting lessons learned, challenges faced, and key takeaways from the process.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://www.sibbr.gov.br/page/cesp/cesp-2024.html>

title: Workshop on biology and taxonomy of Thai wild bees
description: The Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn Natural History Museum (PSUNHM), in collaboration with the Bee Research Unit of the Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Chulalongkorn University, will be holding the “Workshop on Biology and Taxonomy of Thai Wild Bees” from July 16–19, 2025, at the Halabala Wildlife Research Station, Narathiwat Province, Thailand. (registration will be available from May 1 to Jun 31, 2025). All of the course materials will be in Thai.<br class="mb-4">With over 20,000 species of wild bees globally and more than 240 species officially recorded in Thailand, these wild bees play a crucial role in forest ecosystems as pollinators.<br class="mb-4">This workshop highlights the diversity of wild bees in Thailand, not only for economically important honeybees and stingless bees. The lecturer and experts will be led by researchers from Chulalongkorn University under the IUCN SSC Wild Bee Specialist Group – Asia, whose are supported byGBIF’s BIFA5_005 project on “Database and digitization of bees in Thailand” <https://www.gbif.org/project/1tRUhXbB0fXAxKywxgIR4T/digitizing-and-databasing-of-bee-specimens-in-thailand>. The program is designed specifically for local people to understand more about bee biodiversity, biodiversity data and thus increase awareness and conservation mind, this is supported BIFA5_005 project. Particularly, this workshop covers bee biology, taxonomy (down to genus or species level), fieldwork techniques, specimen handling, and the application of bee diversity in pollination ecology research.

title: Virtual Data Use Workshop for Asia
description: The GBIF Asia Regional Support Team is organising a virtual data use workshop to share knowledge of using the GBIF data infrastructure.<br class="mb-4">This course is designed for individuals who work as researchers or technicians in biodiversity research or policy institutions. The instruction provided is particularly useful for those who need or desire to use GBIF-mediated data in their research or analyses.<br class="mb-4">Schedule<br class="mb-4">The workshop has three sections of activities organised into two days:<br class="mb-4"> * 9 June: Section I - Darwin Core Standard and GBIF.org, and Section II - Data quality  * 10 June: Section III - Data processing and pipelines (API, automation, R) Sessions will be held each day beginning at 06:00 UTC and will last approximately 3 hours with a 15-minute break.<br class="mb-4">Participants who attend both sessions will receive a certificate of attendance.<br class="mb-4">Participants in the workshop should possess the following skills and knowledge:<br class="mb-4"> * Basic skills in computer and internet use, as well as spreadsheets.  * Basic understanding of computer-based geographical and statistical analysis tools, e.g., GIS and R, and may have already run analyses using these tools.  * Basic knowledge about geography and biodiversity informatics: geography and mapping concepts, basic taxonomy, and nomenclature rules.  * A good command of English. While efforts are made to provide materials in other languages, instruction/videos will be in English. Application<br class="mb-4">Due to limited training resources, we have 20 seats for this workshop. If we receive more registrations, we will prioritise:<br class="mb-4"> * Instructors who have running curricula ready to incorporate GBIF data-use materials;  * Individuals who have published or are involved in publishing data through GBIF, thus have essential knowledge of the GBIF data chain;  * Individuals who can commit time to disseminate the knowledge learned in the workshop with partners and collaborators in your project by adapting the biodiversity data use training materials to specific contexts and languages while maintaining their instructional value. The deadline for applying is May 18 2025 at 23:59 UTC<br class="mb-4">Apply here <https://bit.ly/2025-du-apply>

title: AgroClim, EUMETSAT and GBIF Workshop
description: The workshop will highlight the Crop Wild Relatives (CWR) use case developed under the Biodiversity Digital Twin project and its integration into the Destination Earth (DestinE) with the AgroClim service. Participants will be introduced to the CWR Digital Twin and explore the graphical user interface developed to enable selecting novel genetic resources from CWRs to enhance crop resilience. They will also see a live demonstration of how to access climate resources from EUMETSAT and DestinE.<br class="mb-4">The event will also explore GBIF’s central role as a research data infrastructure, with a focus onagrobiodiversity <https://www.gbif.org/food> and particularly approaches for enhancing taxonomic backbones to include sub-species crop categories.<br class="mb-4">The workshop will conclude with forward-looking discussions on building future projects for agrobiodiversity and climate resilience.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://www.nhm.uio.no/english/research/projects/biodt/events/agroclim-eumetsat-demonstration-workshop-and-stake.html>

title: Facilitating a world where FAIR and open biodiversity data underpins research, policy, and decision-making
description: Access to FAIR and open primary biodiversity data is crucial for understanding and conserving the natural world.<br class="mb-4">In this presentation, Kate Ingenloff <https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5942-9053> gives an overview of GBIF and introduces the current data model and its potential applications. The presentation is a part of a series of lectures of theGerman National Monitoring Centre for Biodiversity. <https://www.monitoringzentrum.de/><br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://bfn-event.webex.com/webappng/sites/bfn-event/webinar/webinarSeries/register/ce7bd35ef4524b61b688e714e1f259bc>

title: Hosted Portals Community Call
description: A community call with network members who are currently running GBIF's hosted portal service <>.<br class="mb-4">The meeting provides updates on progress aligning GBIF.org and Hosted Portals, as well as addressing community feedback.<br class="mb-4">Anyone not currently involved in a hosted portal who wants to learn more can emailhostedportals@gbif.org <mailto:hostedportals@gbif.org> to request a Zoom link to join this call.

title: Introducing the Darwin Core Data Package
description: During this webinar, we will provide an update on efforts to explore a new data model for GBIF.<br class="mb-4">This work will introduce changes that we aim to propose as a Vocabulary Enhancement <https://github.com/tdwg/vocab/blob/master/vms/maintenance-specification.md#4-vocabulary-enhancements> to theDarwin Core standard <https://dwc.tdwg.org/>, with a public review expected to begin onSeptember 2025<br class="mb-4">The public review will feature:<br class="mb-4"> * A Darwin Core Conceptual Model <https://github.com/gbif/dwc-dp/blob/master/README.md#darwin-core-conceptual-model>, part of a long-awaited Semantic Layer for Darwin Core.  * A Darwin Core Data Package (DwC-DP) Publishing Model <https://github.com/gbif/dwc-dp/blob/master/README.md#darwin-core-data-package-dwc-dp-publishing-model>, enabling the sharing of deeper, richer data than what is currently possible with aDarwin Core Archive <https://ipt.gbif.org/manual/en/ipt/latest/dwca-guide>. We will introduce these developments, the timeline, and explain how you can already begin participating in early testing.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/jsaQm5bSSzixysR5tojhTQ>

title: Regional Training Workshop on Biodiversity Data Mobilization in Hindu Kush Himalaya Region
description: This regional training, organized by International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD), is designed to strengthen the capability of key institutions working for biodiversity management in its Regional Member Countries (RMCs) to manage, standardise and publish biodiversity data; in effect, building a community of data-publishing institutions that can leverage and amplify the use of open access data (for example, GBIF-mediated data) in biodiversity research and decision making.<br class="mb-4">The regional training is supported by GBIF’s Capacity Enhancement Support Programme <https://www.gbif.org/project/CESP2024-006/enhancing-institutional-capacity-for-data-management-in-the-hindu-kush-himalayan-region> and ICIMOD. The National Biodiversity Centre of Bhutan, Zoological Survey of India, Forest Action-Nepal and the National Science Library, Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, China, are providing technical expertise. This collaboration is expected to build future partnerships for joint actions and proposal development. Following this workshop, there will be post-training national dissemination webinars on sensitising other agencies/institutions in the participating countries.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://www.icimod.org/event/ecosystems-landscapes/regional-institutional-capacity-building-for-biodiversity-data-mobilisation-and-management/>

title: From Data to Digital Twins: Empowering Biodiversity Digital Twins with Research Infrastructures
description: This session brings together key partners from GBIF, eLTER, DiSSCo, and LifeWatch ERIC, who share what they achieve through their collaboration with BioDT. They explain how their data, expertise, and technologies contribute to the development of the BioDT prototype Digital Twins - and how the project supports their own missions.<br class="mb-4">Speakers focus on:<br class="mb-4"> * How each RI supports the BioDT project  * What they gain or learn from the cooperation  * Future opportunities and remaining challenges  Register for the event <https://biodt.eu/events/data-digital-twins-empowering-biodiversity-digital-twins-research-infrastructures>

title: Data Use Club seminar: Integrating Remotely Sensed Data with GBIF Mediated Data
description: Join us on 9 July 2025 for a 90-minute session exploring leveraging remote sensing data alongside GBIF’s biodiversity datasets. This session will explore how to access airborne, spaceborne, and in situ remote sensing datasets including LiDAR, imaging spectroscopy and thermal sensor datasets.<br class="mb-4">Using Python and various APIs, this session will give you notebooks to begin the journey of unlocking new possibilities for ecological and biodiversity research by demonstrating how GBIF APIs can be used in conjunction with remote sensing datasets to enhance analyses.<br class="mb-4">Notebooks will be created and sent out a week before the webinar for those who want to follow along with the demonstrations. While this is a technical webinar, feel free to come learn about remote sensing data as there will be short primers and lessons on the sensors too.<br class="mb-4">Speaker Kit Lewers <https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0526-4075><br class="mb-4">This event will be recorded and the recording made available in the week after the event.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/r__lk5-4SUWeZcirHGOLLg>

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: June 2025
description: The Humboldt extension to Darwin Core (https://eco.tdwg.org/ <https://eco.tdwg.org/>) provides a means by which to more explicitly capture the sampling context of biodiversity survey data. The ratification of this extension reinvigorated efforts to expand support for Event data in GBIF and increase the quantity of survey data shared through GBIF implementing Event core with the Humboldt extension.<br class="mb-4">In the upcoming GBIF technical support hour for nodes on 4 June 2025, we will talk about these efforts to increase biodiversity survey data in GBIF. Specifically, we will present a data example implementing the Humboldt extension to Darwin Core (https://eco.tdwg.org/ <https://eco.tdwg.org/>), introduce existing resources, and provide an update on the status of the Survey and Monitoring Data Guide.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/lb1BqHiaTlOjUTFY8yZehA> <br class="mb-4">We will be happy to answer any question relating or not to the topic. Please feel free to post questions in advance onthe discourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/the-humboldt-extension-to-darwin-core/5970> or writehelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.

title: Training on Biodiversity Data Quality and Cleaning (in Portuguese)
description: This hands-on course will explain the principles of data quality and seek their application through data detection and cleaning practices, with practical examples. Data quality is one of the most important aspects that determines the potential use of a dataset. This quality is determined by multiple factors that integrate the information production and processing chain, from the initial registration or capture to the final use and interpretation. The quality of biodiversity data is also associated with its various dimensions, from taxonomy to spatial information, metadata, storage and publication.<br class="mb-4">The course covers the following topics:<br class="mb-4"> * Principles for data quality  * Tools and protocols for data quality  * OpenRefine  * Quality of taxonomic and spatial data  Read more <https://www.gbif.pt/node/621>

title: Training on Publishing Biodiversity Data Through GBIF (in Portuguese)
description: The hands-on course is designed to teach users how to publish biodiversity data through GBIF. This edition of the course includes presentations on how to publish occurrence data derived from DNA (including environmental DNA), and ecological data through the Humboldt extension. The course is aimed at researchers or teachers, curators of biological and natural history collections, public administration or private sector collaborators, protected area managers and members of NGOs who are actively involved in cataloging, monitoring and managing biodiversity data.<br class="mb-4">The course covers the following topics:<br class="mb-4"> * Data standards and organization of biodiversity data  * Publishing data derived from DNA and environmental DNA  * Publishing ecological data with the Humboldt extension  * Data quality control and cleaning  * Publishing data through the GBIF Integrated Publishing Toolkit (IPT) platform  Read more <https://www.gbif.pt/node/622>

title: Hosted Portals Community Call
description: A community call with network members who are currently running GBIF's hosted portal service <>.<br class="mb-4">The meeting provides updates on progress aligning GBIF.org and Hosted Portals, as well as addressing community feedback.<br class="mb-4">Anyone not currently involved in a hosted portal who wants to learn more can emailhostedportals@gbif.org <mailto:hostedportals@gbif.org> to request a Zoom link to join this call.

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: July 2025
description: For the next technical support hour for GBIF nodes on July 2nd at 4:00 pm CEST,Morten <https://www.gbif.org/contact-us/directory?personId=3785&group=secretariat> from the GBIF Engineering team will introduce you to the new GBIF.org portal (demo site).<br class="mb-4">The focus will be on the search interface, custom data dashboards and the new multitaxonomy feature.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZIkdO2tqzouE91hLq2kkkCVYi_qUDYlDQjO> <br class="mb-4">We will be happy to answer any question relating or not to the topic. Please feel free to post questions in advance on thediscourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/t/introducing-the-new-gbif-org-portal/6001> or writehelpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.

title: OpenEPI X Unleash Hackathon 2025
description: The Open Data Hackathon 2025 is a virtual event that brings together aspiring changemakers committed to leveraging open source data to address pressing challenges in Sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America, and South-East Asia. Participants from around the world collaborate to develop innovative, sustainable solutions through coding, user-centered design, data analysis, and strategic thinking.<br class="mb-4">read more <https://developer.openepi.io/hackathon-2025>

title: Animal Taxonomy Summit 2025
description: Celebrating its 110th anniversary, the Zoological Survey of India (ZSI) organizes the Animal Taxonomy Summit 2025 to discuss and deliberate the recent advances in taxonomical research and way forward for this unique subject.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://zsi.org.in/>

title: Esri User Conference
description: Join the GBIF Secretariat at the Esri User Conference <https://www.esri.com/en-us/about/events/uc/overview> in San Diego, United States from 14 - 18 July 2025. This event brings together GIS experts from around the world to discuss innovations and new developments in the space.<br class="mb-4">Find the Secretariat at our co-hosted booth with NatureServe <https://www.natureserve.org/> in the GIS for Good kiosk area, and join the presentation byAndrew Rodrigues <https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5468-2452> at the Biodiversity Data Spotlight <https://uc2025.esri.com/flow/esri/25uc/eventportal/page/detailed-agenda/session/1746471350495001fy3H> session.<br class="mb-4">Biodiversity Data Spotlight <https://uc2025.esri.com/flow/esri/25uc/eventportal/page/detailed-agenda/session/1746471350495001fy3H>Wednesday, 16 July 2025: 2:30 PM - 3:15 PM PDT Session: GH14A: Advances in Climate-Driven Models for Vector-Borne DiseasesExpo GIS for Good Demo Theater | SDCC<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://uc2025.esri.com/flow/esri/25uc/eventportal/page/detailed-agenda/session/1746471350495001fy3H>

title: The Future of Open Research: Reliable, Responsible, Equitable
description: This conference brings together scholars, activists, and policymakers to consider this challenging landscape and discuss the future of open research. The goal is to facilitate the development of open research practices explicitly geared to serve the public interest, which involves interrogating what may constitute that ‘public interest’ to different audiences and in different locations around the world.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://zoom.us/meeting/register/tJIqcOmoqD0jGNElY_zh_8H9XunSJ1s4qkmM>

title: SBDI Days 2026 - Artificial Intelligence in Ecology and Biodiversity Research
description: SBDI Days 2026 <https://biodiversitydata.se> explores how artificial intelligence influences the field of ecology and biodiversity research. The conference is hosted by the [Swedish Biodiversity Data Infrastructure](SBDI - https://biodiversitydata.se), which includesthe Swedish GBIF node <https://www.gbif.org/country/SE/summary>. The program features current developments in areas such as machine learning, digital twins, genetic monitoring using environmental DNA (e-DNA), remote sensing, and robotic biotracking. In addition to technological advances, the conference includes discussions on the ethical considerations of AI, data quality, and approaches to responsible innovation.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://biodiversitydata.se>

title: The thirtieth Conference of the Parties of the UNFCCC COP 30
description: The meeting comprises the thirtieth session of the Conference of the Parties (COP 30), the twentieth session of the Conference of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol (CMP 20), and the seventh session of the Conference of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Paris Agreement (CMA 7).<br class="mb-4"> read more <https://cop30.br/en>

title: GB32: 32nd Meeting of the GBIF Governing Board
description: The 32nd meeting of the GBIF Governing Board and associated events takes place in Bogotá, Colombia.<br class="mb-4">| Date | Event(s) | |-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | 16 October 2025 |Global Nodes Training – Day 1 <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#thursday-16-october-2025> | | 17 October 2025 |Global Nodes Training – Day 2 <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#friday-17-october-2025> Nodes Steering Group meeting <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#friday-17-october-2025> | | 18 October 2025 | Global Nodes Meeting (online attendance possible) <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#saturday-18-october-2025> Budget Committee meeting <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#saturday-18-october-2025> Science Committee meeting <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#saturday-18-october-2025> Icebreaker <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#saturday-18-october-2025> | | 19–20 October 2025 |Executive Committee meeting 1 <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#sunday-19-october-2025> Governing Board meeting Day 1 <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#sunday-19-october-2025> Governing Board meeting Day 2 <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#monday-20-october-2025> Executive Committee meeting 2 <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#monday-20-october-2025> | | 21–24 October 2025 |Living Data <https://www.livingdata2025.com/> |<br class="mb-4">For more information and to register your attendance, please visit the official GB32 website atgb32.gbif.org <https://gb32.gbif.org/>.<br class="mb-4">Questions? If you have any questions regarding the meeting or associated events, don't hesitate to reach out to us atGB32@gbif.org <mailto:GB32@gbif.org>.

title: IUCN World Conservation Congress
description: A once-every-four-years gathering of nature conservation experts, leaders and decision-makers from around the world.<br class="mb-4">The IUCN World Conservation Congress 2025 Forum <https://iucncongress2025.org/> features a range of impactful session types including interactive thematic sessions, speaker pitches, online podcasts, training and capacity building sessions, networking and other exciting events.<br class="mb-4">The Exhibition serves as a dynamic marketplace where IUCN Members, Commissions, businesses, partners, and academic institutions showcase their research, innovations, and conservation projects. Open to both registered Congress participants and the general public.<br class="mb-4"> Read more <https://iucncongress2025.org/>

title: Technical support hour for GBIF nodes: August 2025
description: Join us on the 6th of August at 4:00 pm CEST for the next GBIF Technical Support Hour for Nodes where Tobias Frøslev from the Science team gives us an update on the work concerning the Metabarcording Toolkit (MDT).Tobias presented an earlier version <https://vimeo.com/showcase/10095350/video/912170754> of the tool last year, which has since then matured as part of theMetabarcoding Data Programme <https://www.gbif.org/composition/1LScBrFuZY5JOJLrVhoYFf/metabarcoding-data-programme>.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZMlduipqTMoEtcyFpsn6Jv_YZ-bJlS-z5Fg> <br class="mb-4">We will be happy to answer any question relating or not to the topic and welcome your input on some of the stranger things you have had to deal with a node staff. Please feel free to post questions in advance on thediscourse forum <https://discourse.gbif.org/tag/nodessupporthour> or write helpdesk@gbif.org <mailto:helpdesk@gbif.org>.

title: GBIF: Connecting Open Biodiversity Data with Knowledge and Action
description: Please note that the meeting will be in Spanish. Title: GBIF, conectando datos abiertos de biodiversidad con conocimiento y accion.<br class="mb-4">The meeting is organized by the Latin American group of WILDLABS and will explore how open data can drive research, conservation, and environmental policymaking in the region. This event is an opportunity to learn more about GBIF's work and discover how to join its global network.<br class="mb-4">There will be a presentation by the GBIF regional support team members for Latin America and the Caribbean, Anabela Plos and Leonardo Buitrago. The presentation will provide an overview of the Global Biodiversity Information System (GBIF), explaining what it is, how it works, and how to participate in its network. It will provide an overview of the main tools for accessing, publishing, and analyzing biodiversity data, as well as the opportunities GBIF offers to support scientific research, capacity building, and informed decision-making in conservation and environmental policymaking.<br class="mb-4">The event is aimed at researchers, professionals, decision-makers, students, and individuals interested in using open data to protect and better understand biodiversity.

title: BES2025 British Ecological Society
description: This meeting will bring together ecologists from across the UK and elsewhere, all producing or working with biological survey and monitoring data.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://www.britishecologicalsociety.org/content/bes-annual-meeting-2025/>

title: 2025 Global Nodes Events Launch
description: GBIF node managers and staff (not restricted to those attending the events in Bogotá) are invited to attend a launch for the2025 Global Nodes events <https://gb32.gbif.org/programme#thursday-16-october-2025>. During this Zoom event, you will have an opportunity to preview the agendas for the Global Nodes Training and Global Nodes Meeting to be held in Bogotá Colombia 16-18 October. Even if you are unable to attend the events in Bogotá, we encourage you to attend this Zoom event to learn how you can stay in the loop and receive benefit from the training and meeting after they are concluded. This Zoom event will be recorded.<br class="mb-4"> Register for the event <https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/y1oQ8SgjRZu8dlOIORtdZw#/registration>
